==History== ===Date=== [[File:ChristAsSol.jpg|thumb|right|Mosaic of Jesus as ''Christus Sol'' (Christ the Sun) in Mausoleum M in the third-century necropolis under [[St Peter's Basilica]] in Rome.<ref>Kelly, Joseph F., ''The Origins of Christmas'', Liturgical Press, 2004, pp. 67–69.</ref>]] [[Sextus Julius Africanus]], a historian of the second century, maintained that Jesus of Nazareth was conceived on March 25, which the [[Christian Church]] came to celebrate as the [[Feast of the Annunciation]].<ref name="Kelly2014">{{cite book |last1=Kelly |first1=Joseph F. |title=The Origins of Christmas |date=2014 |publisher=Liturgical Press|isbn=9780814648858 |page=76 |language=English}}</ref> With the term of a pregnancy being nine months, Sextus Julius Africanus held that Jesus was born on December 25, which the [[Western Christian Church]] established as [[Christmas]].<ref name="Kelly2014"/> Recorded in Sextus Julius Africanus's ''Chronographiai'' (221 AD), this thesis is corroborated by an interpretation of [[Gospel of Luke]] that places the appearance of [[Gabriel]] to [[Zechariah (priest)|Zechariah]] on the observance of [[Yom Kippur]] that occurs around October, as "the worshipers were praying outside of the Temple and not within" for "only the priest could enter the Temple at this time to conduct the proper rituals"; because Jesus was six months younger than his cousin [[John the Baptist]], Jesus was conceived in March and born in late December.<ref name="Crump2013">{{cite book |last1=Crump |first1=William D. |title=The Christmas Encyclopedia, 3d ed. |date=2013 |publisher=[[McFarland & Company]] |isbn=9781476605739 |page=95 |language=English}}</ref>
In 274 AD, [[Aurelian|Emperor Aurelian]] made a festival for [[Sol Invictus]] ("The Unconquered Sun"), originally a Syrian deity who was later adopted as the chief deity of the [[Roman Empire]].<ref name="Wainwright2006">{{cite book |last1=Wainwright |first1=Geoffrey |title=The Oxford History of Christian Worship |date=2006 |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |isbn=9780195138863 |page=65 |language=English}}</ref> While some writers believe that this may have influenced the Christian feast of Christmas, other historians such as [[Louis Duchesne]], [[:de:Hieronymus Engberding|Hieronymus Engberding]] and Thomas Talley maintain that the Christian feast of Christmas was already being celebrated and that Aurelian established ''Dies Natalis Solis Invicti'' in order to compete with the Christian feast of Christmas.<ref name="Wainwright2006"/><ref name="Talley1991">{{cite book|last=Talley|first=Thomas J.|title=The Origins of the Liturgical Year|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T_O8F_iGcqkC|accessdate=December 27, 2016|year=1991|publisher=Liturgical Press|isbn=978-0-8146-6075-1|pages=88–91}}</ref>
The Christian [[Council of Tours]] of 567 established [[Advent]] as the season of preparation for Christmas, as well as the season of [[Christmastide]], declaring "the [[Twelve Days of Christmas|twelve days]] between Christmas and Epiphany to be one unified festal cycle", thus giving significance to both December 25 and January 6, a solution that would "coordinate the solar Julian calendar with the lunar calendars of its provinces in the east".<ref name="2008Forbes">{{cite book|last=Forbes|first=Bruce David|title=Christmas: A Candid History|date=1 October 2008|publisher=[[University of California Press]]|isbn=9780520258020|page=27|quote=In 567 the Council of Tours proclaimed that the entire period between Christmas and Epiphany should be considered part of the celebration, creating what became known as the twelve days of Christmas, or what the English called Christmastide. On the last of the twelve days, called Twelfth Night, various cultures developed a wide range of additional special festivities. The variation extends even to the issue of how to count the days. If Christmas Day is the first of the twelve days, then Twelfth Night would be on January 5, the eve of Epiphany. If December 26, the day after Christmas, is the first day, then Twelfth Night falls on January 6, the evening of Epiphany itself. After Christmas and Epiphany were in place, on December 25 and January 6, with the twelve days of Christmas in between, Christians gradually added a period called Advent, as a time of spiritual preparation leading up to Christmas.}}</ref><ref name="Hynes1993">{{cite book|last=Hynes|first=Mary Ellen|title=Companion to the Calendar|year=1993|publisher=Liturgy Training Publications|isbn=9781568540115|page=8|quote=In the year 567 the church council of Tours called the 13 days between December 25 and January 6 a festival season. Up until that time the only other joyful church season was the 50 days between Easter Sunday and Pentecost.}}</ref><ref name="Hill2003">{{cite book|last=Hill|first=Christopher|title=Holidays and Holy Nights: Celebrating Twelve Seasonal Festivals of the Christian Year|year=2003|publisher=Quest Books|isbn=9780835608107|page=91|quote=This arrangement became an administrative problem for the Roman Empire as it tried to coordinate the solar Julian calendar with the lunar calendars of its provinces in the east. While the Romans could roughly match the months in the two systems, the four cardinal points of the solar year--the two equinoxes and solstices--still fell on different dates. By the time of the first century, the calendar date of the winter solstice in Egypt and Palestine was eleven to twelve days later than the date in Rome. As a result the Incarnation came to be celebrated on different days in different parts of the Empire. The Western Church, in its desire to be universal, eventually took them both--one became Christmas, one Epiphany--with a resulting twelve days in between. Over time this hiatus became invested with specific Christian meaning. The Church gradually filled these days with saints, some connected to the birth narratives in Gospels (Holy Innocents' Day, December 28, in honor of the infants slaughtered by Herod; St. John the Evangelist, "the Beloved," December 27; St. Stephen, the first Christian martyr, December 26; the Holy Family, December 31; the Virgin Mary, January 1). In 567, the Council of Tours declared the twelve days between Christmas and Epiphany to become one unified festal cycle.}}</ref>
In Christian belief, the teaching that [[God the Son|God]] came into the world in the [[Incarnation (Christianity)|form of man]] to [[Atonement in Christianity|atone]] for the [[sin]]s of humanity, rather than the exact birth date, is considered to be the primary purpose in celebrating Christmas; the exact date of the birth of Jesus of Nazareth is considered a non-issue.<ref name="Joan Chittister, Phyllis Tickle">{{cite book| title = The Liturgical Year|publisher = [[Thomas Nelson (publisher)|Thomas Nelson]]|quote=Christmas is not really about the celebration of a birth date at all. It is about the celebration of a birth. The fact of the date and the fact of the birth are two different things. The calendrical verification of the feast itself is not really that important ... What is important to the understanding of a life-changing moment is that it happened, not necessarily where or when it happened. The message is clear: Christmas is not about marking the actual birth date of Jesus. It is about the Incarnation of the One who became like us in all things but sin (Heb. 4:15) and who humbled Himself "to the point of death-even death on a cross" (Phil. 2:8). Christmas is a pinnacle feast, yes, but it is not the beginning of the liturgical year. It is a memorial, a remembrance, of the birth of Jesus, not really a celebration of the day itself. We remember that because the Jesus of history was born, the Resurrection of the Christ of faith could happen.| isbn = 978-1-4185-8073-5| date = November 3, 2009}}</ref><ref name="HU">{{cite book| title = The School Journal, Volume 49|publisher = [[Harvard University]]|quote=Throughout the Christian world the 25th of December is celebrated as the birthday of Jesus Christ. There was a time when the churches were not united regarding the date of the joyous event. Many Christians kept their Christmas in April, others in May, and still others at the close of September, till finally December 25 was agreed upon as the most appropriate date. The choice of that day was, of course, wholly arbitrary, for neither the exact date not the period of the year at which the birth of Christ occurred is known. For purposes of commemoration, however, it is unimportant whether the celebration shall fall or not at the precise anniversary of the joyous event.| year = 1894}}</ref><ref name="McGrath2006">{{cite book|author=[[Alister McGrath]]|title=Christianity: An Introduction|date=February 13, 2006|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|language=English |isbn=9781405108997|page=15|quote=For Christians, the precise date of the birth of Jesus is actually something of a non-issue. What really matters is that he was born as a human being, and entered into human history.}}</ref>
During the winter, the burning of logs was a common practice among many cultures across Northern Europe. In Scandinavia, this was known as the [[yule log]] and originally had a pagan significance; after the [[Christianization of Scandinavia]], it may have been incorporated into the Christian celebration of Christmas there, with the pagan significance no longer remaining.<ref name="Collins2010">{{cite book |last1=Collins |first1=Ace |title=Stories Behind the Great Traditions of Christmas |date=2010 |publisher=Zondervan |isbn=9780310873884 |page=191 |language=English}}</ref> However, as there are no existing references to a Christmas log prior to the 16th century, the burning of the Christmas block may have been an early modern invention by Christians unrelated to the pagan practice.<ref name="Weiser1958">{{cite book |last1=Weiser |first1=Franz Xaver |title=Handbook of Christian Feasts and Customs |date=1958 |publisher=[[Harcourt (publisher)|Harcourt]] |language=English}}</ref>
Many other Advent and Christmastide customs developed within the context of Christianity, such as the lighting of the [[Advent wreath]] (invented by [[Lutheran]]s in the 16th century Germany),<ref name="Dues1992">{{cite book |last1=Dues |first1=Greg |title=Catholic Customs & Traditions: A Popular Guide |date=1992 |publisher=Twenty-Third Publications |isbn=9780896225152 |pages=46 |language=English|quote=Probably the most popular tradition today is the lighting of candles on an Advent Wreath in both churches and homes. This custom originated among Lutherans in Germany in the 16th century and quickly became popular in other areas.}}</ref> the marking of an [[Advent calendar]] (first used by Lutherans in the 19th century),<ref name="Mills2010">{{cite book|last=Mills|first=T.J.|title=The Twelve Blessings of Christmas|date=May 10, 2010|publisher=Thomas Nelson Inc.|isbn=9780529124319|page=54|quote=The Advent calendar was first used by Lutherans in the early 19th century. Early printed Advent calendars had Bible verses behind little cardboard doors.}}</ref> the lighting of a [[Christingle]] (invented by [[Moravian Church|Moravians]] in 19th century Britain),<ref name="Thomas2007">{{cite book |last1=Thomas |first1=Nancy Smith |title=Moravian Christmas in the South |date=2007 |publisher=Old Salem Museums & Gardens |isbn=9780807831816 |language=English|quote=A candle-related custom called Christingle appeared sometime in the nineteenth century in British Moravian services.}}</ref> and the viewing of a [[Nativity play]] (first enacted by Catholic monks in 11th century Italy).<ref name="Williams2016">{{cite book |last1=Williams |first1=Victoria |title=Celebrating Life Customs around the World: From Baby Showers to Funerals [3 volumes] |date=2016 |publisher=ABC-CLIO |isbn=9781440836596 |page=245 |language=English}}</ref>
===Puritan era=== [[File:PuritanChristmasBan.jpg|275px|thumb|17th-century public notice in [[Boston]] forbidding Christmas celebration traditions]] Prior to the [[Victorian era]], Christmas in the United States was primarily a religious holiday observed by Christians of the [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]], [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopalian]], and [[Lutheranism|Lutheran]] denominations. Its importance was often considered secondary to that of [[Epiphany (Christian)|Epiphany]] and [[Easter]].
The [[Puritans]], on the other hand, objected to the Christian feast of Christmas,<ref>{{cite book |last1=Hoogs |first1=Frank L. |last2=Langton |first2=William M. |title=Paradise of the Pacific |date=1923 |publisher=F. L. Hoogs |page=92 |language=English|quote=Christmas was abolished by the Puritans when in power, because it had largely become an orgy of dissipation.}}</ref> during the [[English Interregnum]], when England was ruled by a Puritan [[Parliament of England|Parliament]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timetravel-britain.com/05/Dec/ban.shtml |first=Marta |last=Patiño |title=The Puritan Ban on Christmas |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061121055727/http://www.timetravel-britain.com/05/Dec/ban.shtml |archivedate=21 November 2006 }}</ref> Puritans sought to remove elements they viewed as unbiblical, from their practice of Christianity, including those feasts established by the [[Anglicanism|Anglican Church]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Neal |first1=Daniel |title=The History of the Puritans |date=1822 |publisher=William Baynes and Son |page=193 |language=English|quote=They disapproved of the observation of sundry of the church-festivals or holidays, as having no foundation in Scripture, or primitive antiquity.}}</ref> In 1647, the Puritan-led English Parliament banned the celebration of Christmas, replacing it with a day of fasting and considering it "a [[popish]] festival with no biblical justification", and a time of wasteful and immoral behavior.<ref>{{cite web |title= Why Did Cromwell Abolish Christmas? |work= Oliver Cromwell |publisher= The Cromwell Association |year= 2001 |url= http://www.olivercromwell.org/faqs4.htm |accessdate= 28 December 2006}}</ref> Protests followed as pro-Christmas rioting broke out in several cities and for weeks Canterbury was controlled by the rioters, who decorated doorways with holly and shouted [[Royalism|royalist]] slogans.<ref name="Durston">{{cite magazine |last= Durston |first= Chris |url= http://www.historytoday.com/dt_main_allatonce.asp?gid=12890&aid=&tgid=&amid=12890&g12890=x&g9130=x&g30026=x&g20991=x&g21010=x&g19965=x&g19963=x |title= Lords of Misrule: The Puritan War on Christmas 1642–60 |magazine= History Today |date= December 1985 |volume= 35 |issue= 12 |pages= 7–14 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20070310013925/http://www.historytoday.com/dt_main_allatonce.asp?gid=12890&aid=&tgid=&amid=12890&g12890=x&g9130=x&g30026=x&g20991=x&g21010=x&g19965=x&g19963=x |archive-date=10 March 2007 }}</ref> The book ''The Vindication of Christmas'' (London, 1652) argued against the Puritans, and makes note of Old English Christmas traditions, dinner, roast apples on the fire, card playing, dances with "plow-boys" and "maidservants", old Father Christmas and carol singing.<ref>{{cite book |last1= Sandys |first1= William |title= Christmastide: Its History, Festivities and Carols |year= 1852 |publisher= John Russell Smith |location= London |pages= 119–120}}</ref> The [[English Restoration|Restoration]] of [[Charles II of England|King Charles II]] in 1660 ended the ban. ''Poor Robin's Almanack'' contained the lines: "Now thanks to God for Charles return, / Whose absence made old Christmas mourn. / For then we scarcely did it know, / Whether it Christmas were or no."<ref>{{cite book|last=Miall|first=Anthony & Peter|title=The Victorian Christmas Book|year=1978|publisher=Dent|isbn=0-460-12039-5|page=7}}</ref> Many clergymen still disapproved of Christmas celebration. In Scotland, the Presbyterian [[Church of Scotland]] also discouraged observance of Christmas. James VI commanded its celebration in 1618, but attendance at church was scant.<ref>{{cite book |last= Chambers |first= Robert |year= 1885 |title= Domestic Annals of Scotland |page= 211}}{{full citation needed|date= December 2015}}</ref>
In [[Colonial America]], the [[Pilgrim (Plymouth Colony)|Pilgrims]] of [[New England]] disapproved of Christmas.<ref name="Barnett">{{cite book |last=Barnett |first=James Harwood |year=1984 |title=The American Christmas: A Study in National Culture |publisher=Ayer Publishing |isbn=0-405-07671-1 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-sRH9skUh6oC&pg=PA2&lpg=PA3&dq=Christmas+Puritan+New+England&lr=&ie=ISO-8859-1&output=html |page=3}}</ref> The Plymouth Pilgrims put their loathing for the day into practice in 1620 when they spent their first Christmas Day in the New World building their first structure in the New World – thus demonstrating their complete contempt for the day.<ref name="Barnett"/> Non-Puritans in New England deplored the loss of the holidays enjoyed by the laboring classes in England.<ref>{{cite book |last=Innes |first=Stephen |year=1995 |title=Creating the Commonwealth: The Economic Culture of Puritan New England |publisher=[[W.W. Norton & Company]]|isbn=978-0-393-03584-1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9XUKUkulSkIC&pg=PA145&dq=Christmas+Puritan+New+England&ie=ISO-8859-1&output=html |page=145 }}</ref> Christmas observance was outlawed in [[Boston]] in 1659.<ref>{{cite news |first= Rachel N. |last= Schnepper |title= Yuletide's Outlaws |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/15/opinion/the-puritan-war-on-christmas.html?hp&_r=0 |quote= From 1659 to 1681, anyone caught celebrating Christmas in the colony would be fined five shillings. ... |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date= 14 December 2012 |accessdate= 15 December 2012 }}</ref><ref name="Time"/><ref name=week>{{cite news |url= http://theweek.com/article/index/222676/when-americans-banned-christmas |title= When Americans Banned Christmas |work= [[The Week]] |date= 20 December 2011 |access-date= 18 December 2014}}</ref> The ban by the Puritans was revoked in 1681 by an English appointed governor, [[Edmund Andros]], however it was not until the mid-19th century that celebrating Christmas became fashionable in the Boston region.<ref>{{cite book |last=Marling |first=Karal Ann |year=2000 |title=Merry Christmas!: Celebrating America's Greatest Holiday |publisher=Harvard University Press |isbn=0-674-00318-7 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EUc13_ourtYC&pg=PA44&dq=Christmas+Puritan+New+England&ie=ISO-8859-1&output=html |page=44}}</ref> By the [[United States Declaration of Independence|Declaration of Independence]] in 1776, it was not widely celebrated in the US.<ref name="Time">{{cite news |url= http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,1868506_1868508_1868518,00.html |work= [[Time (magazine)|Time]] |title= Top 10 Things You Didn't Know About Christmas |date= 24 December 2008}}</ref>
===19th century=== With the appearance of the [[Oxford Movement]] in the [[Anglican Church]], a revival in the traditional rituals and religious observances associated with [[Christmastide]] occurred.<ref>[[Ronald Hutton]] ''Stations of the Sun: The Ritual Year in England''. 1996. Oxford: Oxford University Press. p. 113. {{ISBN|0-19-285448-8}}.</ref> This ushered in "the development of richer and more symbolic forms of worship, the building of neo-Gothic churches, and the revival and increasing centrality of the keeping of Christmas itself as a Christian festival" as well as "special charities for the poor" in addition to "special services and musical events".<ref name="Rowel1993">{{cite journal|last=Rowell|first=Geoffrey|date=December 1993|journal=[[History Today]]|volume=43|issue=12|quote=There is no doubt that A Christmas Carol is first and foremost a story concerned with the Christian gospel of liberation by the grace of God, and with incarnational religion which refuses to drive a wedge between the world of spirit and the world of matter. Both the Christmas dinners and the Christmas dinner-carriers are blessed; the cornucopia of Christmas food and feasting reflects both the goodness of creation and the joy of heaven. It is a significant sign of a shift in theological emphasis in the nineteenth century from a stress on the Atonement to a stress on the Incarnation, a stress which found outward and visible form in the sacramentalism of the Oxford Movement, the development of richer and more symbolic forms of worship, the building of neo-Gothic churches, and the revival and increasing centrality of the keeping of Christmas itself as a Christian festival. ... In the course of the century, under the influence of the Oxford Movement’s concern for the better observance of Christian festivals, Christmas became more and more prominent. By the later part of the century cathedrals provided special services and musical events, and might have revived ancient special charities for the poor – though we must not forget the problems for large: parish-church cathedrals like Manchester, which on one Christmas Day had no less than eighty couples coming to be married (the signing of the registers lasted until four in the afternoon). The popularity of Dickens' A Christmas Carol played a significant part in the changing consciousness of Christmas and the way in which it was celebrated. The popularity of his public readings of the story is an indication of how much it resonated with the contemporary mood, and contributed to the increasing place of the Christmas celebration in both secular and religious ways that was firmly established by the end of the nineteenth century.|accessdate=28 December 2016|language=English|url=http://www.historytoday.com/geoffrey-rowell/dickens-and-construction-christmas|title=Dickens and the Construction of Christmas}}</ref> Historian [[Ronald Hutton]] believes that the current state of observance of Christmas is largely the result of a mid-[[Victorian era|Victorian]] revival of the holiday, spearheaded by [[Charles Dickens]], who "linked worship and feasting, within a context of social reconciliation".<ref name="Hutton2001">{{cite book|last=Hutton|first=Ronald|title=Stations of the Sun: A History of the Ritual Year in Britain|date=15 February 2001|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|language=English |isbn=9780191578427|page=113}}</ref> Dickens was not the first author to celebrate Christmastide in literature, but it was he who superimposed his humanitarian vision of the holiday upon the public, an idea that has been termed as Dickens' "Carol Philosophy".<ref name="Forbes2008">{{cite book|last=Forbes|first=Bruce David|title=Christmas: A Candid History|date=1 October 2008|publisher=[[University of California Press]]|isbn=9780520258020|page=62|quote=What Dickens ''did'' advocate in his story was "the spirit of Christmas." Sociologist James Barnett has described it as Dickens's "Carol Philosophy," which "combined religious and secular attitudes toward to celebration into a humanitarian pattern. It excoriated individual selfishness and extolled the virtues of brotherhood, kindness, and generosity at Christmas. . . .Dickens preached that at Christmas men should forget self and think of others, especially the poor and the unfortunate." The message was one that both religious and secular people could endorse.}}</ref>
[[File:Gifts xmas.jpg|thumb|Modern celebrations of Christmas include more commercial activity in comparison with those of the past.]] Historian Stephen Nissenbaum contends that the modern celebration in the United States was developed in New York State from defunct and imagined Dutch and English traditions in order to refocus the holiday from one where groups of young men went from house to house demanding alcohol and food into one centered on the happiness of children. He notes that there was a deliberate effort to prevent children from becoming greedy in response.<ref name="auto">{{cite book |first= Stephen |last= Nissenbaum |year= 1997 |title= The Battle for Christmas |location= New York |publisher= Vintage Books |page= |isbn= 0-679-74038-4}}{{page needed|date= December 2015}}</ref> Christmas was not proclaimed a holiday by the [[United States Congress]] until 1870.<ref name="Time"/>
===20th century=== In the early 20th century, Christian writers such as [[C. S. Lewis]] noted what he saw as a distinct split between the religious and commercialized observance of Christmas, the latter of which he deplored.<ref name="LeDonne2016">{{cite book |last1=LeDonne |first1=Anthony |title=Near Christianity |date=2016 |publisher=Zondervan |isbn=9780310522973 |language=English|quote=C.S. Lewis wrote of his revulsion for the commercialization of "Xmas" in several personal letters. Once, when asked about his view on the holiday, he wrote ... 'One is a religious festival. This is important and obligatory for Christians; but as it can be of no interest to anyone else, I shall naturally say no more of it here. ... But the third thing called Christmas is unfortunately everyone's business. I mean of course the commercial racket'.}}</ref> In ''Xmas and Christmas: A Lost Chapter from Herodotus'', Lewis gives a [[satire]] of the observance of two simultaneous holidays in "Niatirb" ("Britain" spelled backwards) from the supposed view of the [[ancient Greek]] historian [[Herodotus]] (484–425 BC). One of the holidays, "Exmas", is observed by a flurry of compulsory commercial activity and expensive indulgence in alcoholic beverages. The other, "Crissmas", is observed in Niatirb's temples. Lewis's narrator asks a [[priest]] why they kept Crissmas on the same day as Exmas. He receives the reply: {{quote|"It is not lawful, O Stranger, for us to change the date of Crissmas, but would that Zeus would put it into the minds of the Niatirbians to keep Exmas at some other time or not to keep it at all. For Exmas and the Rush distract the minds even of the few from sacred things. And we indeed are glad that men should make merry at Crissmas; but in Exmas there is no merriment left." And when I asked him why they endured the Rush, he replied, "It is, O Stranger, a racket. . ."<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www-personal.umich.edu/~dunlapg/Xmas_and_Christmas.html |title= Exmas and Christmas: A Lost Chapter from Herodotus |first= C. S. |last= Lewis |author-link= C. S. Lewis |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20060525055426/http://www-personal.umich.edu/~dunlapg/Xmas_and_Christmas.html |archivedate= 25 May 2006 |df= dmy-all }}</ref>}}
The Soviet Union (until 1936), and certain other [[Communist]] regimes, banned overtly religious Christmas observances in accordance with the Marxist-Leninist doctrine of [[state atheism]].<ref name="Harper1999">{{cite book |last1=Harper |first1=Timothy |title=Moscow Madness: Crime, Corruption, and One Man's Pursuit of Profit in the New Russia |date=1999 |publisher=McGraw-Hill |isbn=9780070267008 |page=72 |language=en}}</ref> In 1920s USSR, the [[League of Militant Atheists]] encouraged school pupils to campaign against Christmas traditions, such as the Christmas tree, and encouraged them to spit on [[crucifix]]es as protest against this holiday; the League established an antireligious holiday to be the 31st of each month as a replacement.<ref name="Ramet2005">{{cite book |last= Ramet |first= Sabrina Petra |title= Religious Policy in the Soviet Union |year= 2005 |publisher= [[Cambridge University Press]] |isbn= 9780521022309 |page= 138 |quote= The League sallied forth to save the day from this putative religious revival. ''Antireligioznik'' obliged with so many articles that it devoted an entire section of its annual index for 1928 to anti-religious training in the schools. More such material followed in 1929, and a flood of it the next year. It recommended what Lenin and others earlier had explicitly condemned—carnivals, farces, and games to intimidate and purge the youth of religious belief. It suggested that pupils campaign against customs associated with Christmas (including Christmas trees) and Easter. Some schools, the League approvingly reported, staged an anti-religious day on the 31st of each month. Not teachers but the League's local set the programme for this special occasion.}}</ref><ref name="Zugger2001">{{cite book |last= Zugger |first= Christopher Lawrence |title= Catholics of the Soviet Empire from Lenin Through Stalin |year= 2001 |publisher= [[Syracuse University Press]] |isbn= 9780815606796 |page= 210 |quote= As observed by Nicholas Brianchaninov, writing in 1929–1930, after the NEP and just as the worst of collectivization was beginning, the Soviets deemed it necessary to drive into the heads of the people the axiom that religion was the synthesis of everything most harmful to humanity. It must be presented as the enemy of man and society, of life and learning, of progress. . . . In caricatures, articles, ''Bezbozhnik'', ''Antireligioznik'', League of Militant Atheists propaganda and films. School courses [were give] on conducting the struggle against religion (how to profane a church, break windows, objects of piety). The young, always eager to be with the latest trend, often responded to such propaganda. In Moscow in 1929 children were brought to spit on the crucifixes at Christmas. Priests in Tiraspol diocese were sometimes betrayed by their own young parishioners, leading to their imprisonment and even death, and tearing their families apart.}}</ref>
Most customs traditionally associated with Christmas, such as decorated trees, presents, and [[Ded Moroz]] (Father Frost), were later reinstated in Soviet society, but tied to [[New Year's Day]] instead; this tradition remains as of the present day.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lc.org/index.cfm?PID=14100&PRID=1141 |title= Christmas According to Marx and Lenin, by Ronald Reagan |publisher= lc.org |date= 22 December 2011 |accessdate= 31 December 2012 }}{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> It should, however, be noted that most Russian Christians are of the [[Russian Orthodox Church|Orthodox]] community, whose religious festivals (Christmas, Easter etc.) do not necessarily coincide precisely with those of the main western Christian churches (Catholic or Protestant), because of continued connection of the church calendar to the [[Julian calendar]].
Likewise, in [[Nazi Germany]], "because Nazi ideologues saw organized religion as an enemy of the totalitarian state, propagandists sought to deemphasize—or eliminate altogether—the Christian aspects of the holiday" and as a result "propagandists tirelessly promoted numerous Nazified Christmas songs, which replaced Christian themes with the regime's racial ideologies."<ref name="Perry2015">{{cite news|title=How the Nazis co-opted Christmas: A history of propaganda|last=Perry|first=Joseph|date=24 December 2015|work=The Washington Post|language=English}}</ref>
==Present-day controversy== ===United States=== The expression "the War on Christmas" has been used in the media to denote Christmas-related controversies.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://edition.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/12/18/war.on.christmas/index.html |publisher= [[CNN]] |title= Heated Debate Again over 'War on Christmas' Claims |first= Kristi |last= Keck |date= 18 December 2009 |accessdate= 25 December 2012}}</ref> The term gained notability due in part to its use by [[conservatism|conservative]] commentators such as [[Peter Brimelow]] and [[Bill O'Reilly (commentator)|Bill O'Reilly]] beginning in the early 2000s.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1868542,00.html |title= A Brief History of the War on Christmas |work= Time |last= Altman |first= Alex |date= 24 December 2008 |accessdate= 25 December 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2008/11/06/oreillys-war-on-christmas_n_141896.html |title= O'Reilly's War on Christmas Goes Retail |date= 7 December 2008 |first= Jason |last= Linkins |work= The Huffington Post |accessdate= 21 December 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://content.usatoday.com/communities/religion/post/2008/12/60101216/1 |title= Mandatory 'Merry Christmas' Line May Lose Its Lilt |first= Lynn |last= Grossman |date= 18 December 2008 |work= USA Today |accessdate= 21 December 2008}}</ref>
The claim of Brimelow, O'Reilly and others was that any specific mention of the term "Christmas" or its [[religious]] aspects was being increasingly [[censorship|censored]], avoided, or discouraged by a number of advertisers, retailers, government (prominently schools), and other public and secular organizations. In the United States and Canada, where the use of the term "Holidays" is most prevalent, opponents have denounced its usage and avoidance of using the term "Christmas" as being [[political correctness|politically correct]].<ref name="Guardian"/><ref name="Forbes"/><ref name="Taylor"/>
[[Jeff Schweitzer]], a commentator for ''[[The Huffington Post]]'', addressed the position of commentators such as O'Reilly, stating that "There is no war on Christmas; the idea is absurd at every level. Those who object to being forced to celebrate another's religion are drowning in Christmas in a sea of Christianity dominating all aspects of social life. An 80 percent majority can claim victimhood only with an extraordinary flight from reality."<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jeff-schweitzer/a-war-on-reason-not-on-ch_b_6265932.html |title= A War on Reason, Not on Christmas |first= Jeff |last= Schweitzer |date= 3 December 2014 |work= The Huffington Post |accessdate= 12 December 2014}}</ref>
Heather Long, an American columnist for ''[[The Guardian]]'', addressed the "politically correct" question in America over use of the term "holidays", writing, "people who are clearly celebrating Christmas in their homes tend to be conflicted about what to say in the workplace or at school. No one wants to offend anyone or make assumptions about people's religious beliefs, especially at work."<ref name="Guardian"/>
[[Christmas Day]] is recognized as an official [[federal holiday]] by the United States government.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.opm.gov/fedhol/2007.asp |title= 2007 Federal Holidays |publisher= [[United States Office of Personnel Management]] |accessdate=25 December 2012}}</ref> The [[American Civil Liberties Union]] argues that government-funded displays of Christmas imagery and traditions violate the U.S. Constitution—specifically the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]], which prohibits the [[Establishment Clause|establishment]] by Congress of a [[State religion|national religion]]; on the other hand the [[Alliance Defending Freedom]], an organization promoting the principle of religious freedom, believes that Christmas displays are consistent with the First Amendment, as well as court rulings that have repeatedly upheld [[accommodationism]].<ref name="Bowler2016">{{cite book |last1=Bowler |first1=Gerry |title=Christmas in the Crosshairs: Two Thousand Years of Denouncing and Defending the World's Most Celebrated Holiday |date=2016 |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |isbn=9780190499013 |pages=214}}</ref> The debate over whether religious displays should be placed within [[Public school (government funded)|public schools]], courthouses, and other government buildings has been heated in recent years.<ref>{{cite magazine |last= Ostling |first= Richard |title=Have Yourself a Merry Little Lawsuit This Season |magazine= [[Buffalo Law Journal]] |date= 1 December 2005 |volume= 77 |issue= 96 |pages= 1–4}}</ref>
In some cases, popular aspects of Christmas, such as [[Christmas tree]]s, lights, and decorating are still prominently showcased, but are associated with unspecified "holidays" rather than with Christmas.<ref name="Forbes"/> The controversy also includes objections to policies that prohibit government or schools from forcing unwilling participants to take part in Christmas ceremonies. In other cases, the Christmas tree,<ref>{{cite news |title= VA Bans Christmas Trees as Holiday Decorations in Public Areas |url= http://wspa.com/2015/11/20/va-bans-christmas-trees-as-holiday-decorations-in-public-areas/ |location= Spartanburg, SC |publisher= [[WSPA-TV]] |accessdate= 14 December 2015 |quote= Christmas trees will not be allowed at the Salem VA Medical Center this holiday season in public areas. 'Displays must not promote any religion. Please note that trees (regardless of the types of ornaments used) have been deemed to promote the Christian religion and will not be permitted in any public areas this year,' reads an email sent to employees.}}</ref> as well as Nativity scenes, have not been permitted to be displayed in public settings altogether.<ref>{{cite web |last1= Porter |first1= Joel |url= http://www.wndu.com/home/headlines/Federal-judge-rules-against-Concord-High-School-Nativity-scene-360051111.html |title= Federal Judge Rules Against Concord High School Nativity Scene |location= South Bend, IN |publisher= [[WNDU-TV]] |accessdate= 14 December 2015 |quote= An Elkhart high school Christmas concert will have to scrap part of its performance following a court ruling. US district court judge Jon Deguilio granted the Freedom From Religion Foundation a preliminary injunction. That means Concord High School is not allowed to portray a live Nativity scene in its Christmas Spectacular, which opens in less than two weeks.}}</ref> Also, several US chain retailers, such as [[Walmart]], [[Macy's]], and [[Sears]], have experimented with greeting their customers with "[[Happy Holidays]]" or "[[Season's Greetings]]" rather than with "[[Christmas and holiday season#Merry Christmas and Happy Christmas|Merry Christmas]]".<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.snopes.com/politics/christmas/walmart.asp |title= An Unmerried Woman |work= Snopes.com |accessdate= 25 December 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/money/industries/retail/2006-11-08-christmas-usat_x.htm |title= Wal-Mart Wishes You a Merry Christmas |work= USA Today |date= 8 November 2006 |first= Jayne |last= O'Donnell |accessdate= 25 December 2012}}</ref>
Supreme Court rulings, starting with ''[[Lynch v. Donnelly]]'' in 1984, have permitted religious themes in government-funded Christmas displays that had "legitimate secular purposes". Since these rulings have been splintered and have left governments uncertain of their limits, many such displays have included secular elements such as reindeer, snowmen and elves along with the religious elements.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://au.org/church-state/december-2007-church-state/featured/is-there-a-%E2%80%98war-on-christmas%E2%80%99 |title= Is There a 'War on Christmas'? |first= Rob |last= Boston |date= December 2007 |publisher= [[Americans United]] |accessdate= 25 December 2012 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150909203239/https://www.au.org/church-state/december-2007-church-state/featured/is-there-a-%E2%80%98war-on-christmas%E2%80%99 |archive-date= 9 September 2015 |dead-url= yes |df= dmy-all }}</ref> Other recent court cases have brought up additional issues such as the inclusion of [[Christmas carols]] in [[Public school (government funded)|public school]] performances, but none of these cases have reached the [[Supreme Court of the United States]].
A controversy regarding these issues arose in 2002, when the New York City public school system banned the display of [[Nativity scene]]s but allowed the display of less overtly religious symbols such as Christmas trees, Hanukkah menorahs, and the Muslim star and crescent.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2002/12/11/nyregion/lawsuit-attacks-schools-ban-on-nativity-scenes.html |title= Lawsuit Attacks Schools' Ban on Nativity Scenes |first= Daniel |last= Wakin |date= 11 December 2002 |work= The New York Times |accessdate= 25 December 2012}}</ref> The school system successfully defended its policy in ''Skoros v. City of New York'' (2006).<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.csmonitor.com/2007/0222/p04s01-ussc.html |title= Nativity Scene Is too Religious for New York City Schools |work= [[The Christian Science Monitor]] |first= Warren |last= Richey |date= 22 February 2007 |accessdate= 8 December 2008}}</ref>
====Retailer controversies==== Since at least 2005, religious conservative groups and media in the United States, such as the [[American Family Association]] (AFA) and [[Liberty Counsel]], have called for [[boycott]]s of various prominent secular organizations, particularly retail giants, demanding that they use the term "Christmas" rather, than solely "holiday" in their print, TV, online, and in-store marketing and advertising. This was also seen by some as containing a hidden anti-Jewish message. All of the major retailers named denied the charges.<ref>{{cite news |last= Cohen |first= Adam |title= Commercialize Christmas, or Else |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2005/12/07/opinion/07iht-edcohen.html?_r=0 |accessdate= 14 November 2012 |newspaper= The New York Times |date= 7 December 2005}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last= Popper |first= Nathaniel |title= Boycotts Bloom as Religious Conservatives Wage Battle Over Christmas |url= http://forward.com/articles/1757/boycotts-bloom-as-religious-conservatives-wage-bat/#ixzz2CE0rcvy2 |accessdate= 14 November 2012 |newspaper= [[The Jewish Daily Forward]] |location= New York |date= 16 December 2005}}</ref>
=====2000s===== *The [[Sears Holdings Corporation]] (which owns [[Sears, Roebuck and Company|Sears]] and [[Kmart]]) altered their marketing policies from using the term "holiday" to using the term "Christmas". The change of policy included the distribution of "Merry Christmas" signs to stores nationwide, and the changing of the term "holiday" to "Christmas" on their website and in stores.<ref>{{cite news |title= Sears Puts 'Merry Christmas' Signs in Its Stores |url= http://archive.newsmax.com/archives/ic/2005/12/7/121624.shtml |accessdate= 30 December 2012 |publisher= NewsMax.com |date= 7 December 2005 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071119024910/http://archive.newsmax.com/archives/ic/2005/12/7/121624.shtml |archivedate= 19 November 2007 |df= dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title= Target, Sears Say They'll Include ‘Christmas' |url= http://sites.silaspartners.com/partner/Article_Display_Page/0,,PTID314408_CHID657798_CIID2142370,00.html |first= Tom |last= Strode |accessdate= 30 December 2012 |publisher= Silas Partners}}</ref> *In 2005, [[Walmart]] was criticized by the [[Catholic League (U.S.)|Catholic League]] for avoiding the word "Christmas" in any of their marketing efforts.<ref name="merry_christmas" /> The company had downplayed the term "Christmas" in much of its advertising for several years.<ref>{{cite news |title= Wal-Mart Opts for 'Christmas' Marketing |url= http://www.nbcnews.com/id/15639425/#.UN-nLHcer5M |accessdate= 5 December 2006 |publisher= [[MSNBC]] |date= 15 November 2006}}</ref> This caused some backlash among the public, prompting some groups to pass around [[petition]]s and threaten boycotts against the company, as well as several other prominent retailers that practiced similar obscurations of the holiday.<ref name="merry_christmas"/> In 2006, in response to the public outcry, Wal-Mart announced that they were amending their policy and would be using "Christmas" rather than "holiday". Among the changes, they noted that the former "Holiday Shop" would become the "Christmas Shop", and that there would be a "countin' down the days to Christmas" feature.<ref name="merry_christmas"/> *In 2005, [[Target Corporation]] was criticized by the American Family Association for their decision not to use the term "Christmas" in any of their in-store, online, or print advertising.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.snopes.com/politics/christmas/target.asp |title= Merry Christmas Target |work= Snopes.com |date= 9 December 2005}}</ref> The AFA initiated a nationwide boycott of the Target Corporation, resulting in over 700,000 petition signatures. Within a week of initiating the boycott, the AFA received an official letter from Target which indicated that they would begin incorporating the term "Christmas" in their advertising: "Over the course of the next few weeks, our advertising, marketing and merchandising will become more specific to the holiday that is approaching—referring directly to holidays like Christmas and Hanukkah. For example, you will see reference to Christmas in select television commercials, circulars and in-store signage." <ref>{{cite news |title= Target Includes 'Christmas,' AFA Drops Boycott |url= http://archive.newsmax.com/archives/ic/2005/12/9/134058.shtml |accessdate= 30 December 2012 |date= 9 December 2005 |publisher= NewsMax.com |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120921233223/http://archive.newsmax.com/archives/ic/2005/12/9/134058.shtml |archivedate= 21 September 2012 |df= dmy-all }}</ref> *When it was revealed in November 2006 that Wal-Mart would be using the term "Christmas" in their advertising campaign, an article about the issue initiated by ''[[USA Today]]'' pointed out that [[Best Buy#2006 Christmas controversy|Best Buy Corporation]] would be among the retailers that would not be using "Christmas" at all in their advertising that year. Dawn Bryant, a Best Buy spokeswoman, stated: "We are going to continue to use the term holiday because there are several holidays throughout that time period, and we certainly need to be respectful of all of them."<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/15639425/ |title= Wal-Mart Opts for 'Christmas' Marketing |agency= Associated Press |publisher= MSNBC |date= 15 November 2006 |accessdate= 28 January 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.snopes.com/politics/christmas/bestbuy.asp |title= Best Buy Christmas Ban |publisher= Snopes.com |accessdate= 30 December 2012}}</ref> The AFA launched a campaign against Best Buy's policy.<ref>{{cite news |title= War on Christmas Comes to Minnesota |url= http://minnesotaindependent.com/50133/war-on-christmas-comes-to-minnesota |first= Andy |last= Birkey |accessdate= 30 December 2012 |date= 19 November 2009 |work= [[The Minnesota Independent]] }}</ref> In reaction to the same policy, the [[Catholic League (U.S.)|Catholic League]] placed Best Buy on its 2006 Christmas Watch List.<ref>{{cite news |title= Call it Christ's Mass and Let Best Buy Keep the Holiday |url= http://www.firstthings.com/onthesquare/2011/12/call-it-christs-mass-and-let-best-buy-keep-the-holiday/russell-e-saltzman |accessdate= 30 December 2012 |date= 22 December 2011 |first= Russell |last= Saltzman |publisher= FirstThings.com}}</ref> *In late October 2008, U.S. hardware retailer [[The Home Depot]] was criticized by the AFA for using terms such as "holiday" and "Hanukkah" on their website, but avoiding the term "Christmas".<ref>{{cite news |title= The Right's Bogus War on Christmas |url= http://www.laprogressive.com/the-rights-bogus-war-on-christmas/ |accessdate= 30 December 2012 |first= Irene |last= Monroe |work= LA Progressive}}</ref> The retailer responded by saying they will be adjusting their website to make references to Christmas more prominent.<ref>{{cite news |title= Home Depot: Hanukkah, Yes! Holidays, Yes! Christmas, No! |url= https://thescroogereport.wordpress.com/tag/home-depot/ |accessdate= 30 December 2012 |date= 29 October 2008 |work=TheScroogeReport}}</ref> [[Snopes.com]] later stated that the AFA's characterization of Home Depot's advertising was false, as the retailer's advertising had initially included several instances of the word "Christmas".<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.snopes.com/politics/christmas/homedepot.asp |title= Home Depot Christmas |work= Snopes.com |accessdate= 8 December 2008}}</ref> *On 11 November 2009, the AFA called for a "limited two-month boycott" of [[Gap (clothing retailer)|Gap, Inc]] over what they claimed was the "company's censorship of the word 'Christmas.'"<ref>{{cite web |url= http://action.afa.net/Detail.aspx?id=2147489466 |title= Boycott Gap, Old Navy and Banana Republic this Christmas |publisher= [[American Family Association]] |date= 11 November 2009 |accessdate= 31 December 2012 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130113041919/http://action.afa.net/Detail.aspx?id=2147489466 |archivedate= 13 January 2013 |df= dmy-all }}</ref> In an advertising campaign launched by Gap on 12 November, the term "Christmas" was both spoken and printed on their website at least once, and a television ad entitled "Go Ho Ho" featured lyrics such as "Go Christmas, Go Hanukkah, Go Kwanzaa, Go Solstice" and "whatever holiday you Wanna-kah".<ref>{{cite news |url= http://content.usatoday.com/communities/Religion/post/2009/11/the-gap-ads--happy-do-whatever-you-wannukah-reignites-war-on-christmas-debate/1?loc=interstitialskip#.UOGv-ncer5M |title= The Gap's 'Happy Whatever-you-Wannukah' Ad Reignites 'War on Christmas' Debate |first= Leslie |last= Miller |work= USA Today |date= 23 November 2009 |accessdate= 6 December 2009}}</ref> On 17 November, AFA responded to this campaign by condemning the ads for references to the "pagan holiday" of [[winter solstice|solstice]], and declined to call off the boycott.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://action.afa.net/Detail.aspx?id=2147489678 |title= Gap Responds: Should the Boycott End or Not? You Decide |publisher= American Family Association |date= 17 November 2009 |accessdate= 31 December 2012 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130317203716/http://action.afa.net/Detail.aspx?id=2147489678 |archivedate= 17 March 2013 |df= dmy-all }}</ref> On 24 November, the AFA ended the boycott, after learning from Gap's corporate vice president of communications that the company planned to launch a new commercial with a "very strong Christmas theme".<ref name="cp-verystrongtheme">{{cite web|title='Very Strong' Christmas Ad Prompts AFA to Suspend Gap Boycott|url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/afa-christians-can-now-buy-gap-inc-christmas-gifts-42014/|website=Christian Post|accessdate=2 December 2016}}</ref>
=====2010s===== * On 24 November 2010, the branch manager of [[Chase Bank]] in Southlake, Texas told Antonio Morales that a Christmas tree he had donated to the branch had to be taken down per JPMorgan Chase's policy to use only decorations supplied by the company. Bank spokesperson Greg Hassell stated that the company-provided decorations are designed to be "something everyone is comfortable with, regardless of how they celebrate the season."<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.star-telegram.com/2010/12/02/2676274/jpmorgan-chase-orders-southlake.html#ixzz181yBdTzh |title= Chase Orders Southlake Bank to Remove Christmas Tree |first= Terry |last= Evans |work= [[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]] |date= 3 December 2010 |accessdate= 13 December 2010}}</ref> * Also in 2010, [[Wachovia Bank]] was briefly rumored to have banned Christmas trees from its local branches in favor of poinsettias. In response to complaints, the company affirmed that Christmas trees were permitted to be displayed and decorated by branch employees.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.christianpost.com/news/bank-allows-christmas-trees-in-branch-offices-47971/ |title= Wachovia Bank Allows Christmas Trees in Branch Offices |last= Samuel |first= Stephanie |newspaper= The Christian Post |date= 7 December 2010 |accessdate= 8 November 2014}}</ref> * In November 2010, the word "Christmas" on two signs at [[Christmas Village, Philadelphia|Philadelphia's Christmas Village]] was removed by the organizers after complaints, but restored three days later after the mayor intervened.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://abclocal.go.com/wpvi/story?section=news/local&id=7820429 |title= 'Christmas' Returns to Philly's Christmas Village |first= Sarah |last= Bloomquist |location= Philadelphia |publisher= [[WPVI-TV]] |date= 2 December 2010 |accessdate= 31 December 2012}}</ref> * According to NetEase, on the Christmas Day of 2014, a "Boycotting Christmas" campaign launched in downtown [[Changsha]], [[Hunan Province]], China.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://news.163.com/photoview/00AP0001/81581.html#p=AEASMLPC00AP0001 |title= 长沙现大学生着汉服举标语"抵制圣诞节" |trans-title= |work= NetEase |publisher= CFP |date= 25 December 2014 |accessdate= 19 November 2015}}</ref> Also in 2014, [[Northwest University (China)|Northwest University]] closed the campus completely on the Christmas Eve, and all of the requests for leave were rejected by the school officials. * In November 2015, the coffee shop chain [[Starbucks]] introduced Christmas-themed cups colored in solid red and containing no ornamentation besides the Starbucks logo, contrasting previous designs which featured winter-related imagery, and non-religious Christmas symbols such as [[reindeer]] and [[Christmas ornament|ornaments]]. On 5 November, a video was posted on [[Facebook]] by evangelist and self-proclaimed "[[Internet celebrity|social media personality]]" [[Joshua Feuerstein]], in which he accused Starbucks of "hating Jesus" by removing Christmas-oriented imagery from the cup, followed by him "tricking" a barista into writing "Merry Christmas" on the cup, and encouraging others to do the same. The video became a [[viral video]], spurring discussions and commentary: businessman and [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 president-candidate]] (later elected) [[Donald Trump]] supported Feuerstein's claim by suggesting a boycott of Starbucks, stating that "If I become president, we're all going to be saying 'Merry Christmas' again." Many social media users, including other Christians, perceived the criticism to be an overreaction.<ref name="cbc-redcups">{{cite web |title= Brouhaha over Starbucks Red Cups More of a Joke than a Controversy |url= http://www.cbc.ca/news/trending/starbucks-red-holiday-cups-controversy-jokes-and-backlash-1.3312326 |publisher= CBC News |accessdate= 12 November 2015}}</ref><ref name="wp-trumpcups">{{cite news |title= Donald Trump Suggests a Boycott of Starbucks and Its Plain Red Cups |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2015/11/09/donald-trump-suggests-a-boycott-of-starbucks-and-its-plain-red-cups/ |accessdate= 12 November 2015 |work= [[Washington Post]] }}</ref><ref name="fortune-redcup">{{cite news |title= Here's Why People Are Mad About Starbucks' Red Cups |url= http://fortune.com/2015/11/09/starbucks-red-cups/ |work=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] |accessdate= 12 November 2015}}</ref> In contrast to the controversy, the colour red has been associated with Christmas since at least the 19th century,<ref>{{cite web |title=How Red And Green Became The Colors Of Christmas |url=https://www.npr.org/2016/12/20/506215632/how-red-and-green-became-the-colors-of-christmas?t=1536049642597 |website=[[National Public Radio]] (NPR) |accessdate=4 September 2018}}</ref> and is often present in [[Christmas decorations]] and Christian services, such as the red ribbon that is tied around the [[Orange (fruit)|oranges]] used for [[Christingle]]s. Also in 2015 [[Resolution 564]] received 36 sponsors including [[Doug Lamborn]] to assert Christmas in public.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2015/dec/17/newt-gingrich-war-christmas/ |title=The war on Christmas |first=Newt |last=Gingrich |date=17 December 2015 |work=[[Washington Times]] |quote=Rep. Doug Lamborn of Colorado took a small but important step in Congress this week when he introduced a resolution, H. Res. 564, along with 35 cosponsors, to reassert the place of Christmas in the public square. The resolution “recognizes the importance of the symbols and traditions of Christmas; strongly disapproves of attempts to ban references to Christmas; and expresses support for the use of these symbols and traditions by those who celebrate Christmas.”}}</ref> [[Newt Gingrich]]'s anti-war holiday stance resonated in popular culture for years.<ref>{{cite episode |series=Bob's Burgers |date=21 October 2018 |title=Nightmare on Ocean Avenue Street |first=Gene |last=Belcher |minutes=5 |quote=It's a war on Halloween! Newt Gingrich warned us about this!}}</ref>
===Canada=== In 2007, a controversy arose<ref name="NationalPost" /> when a public school in Ottawa, Ontario, planned to have the children in its primary choir sing a version of the song "Silver Bells" with the word "Christmas" replaced by "festive"; the concert also included the songs "Candles of Christmas" and "It's Christmas" with the original lyrics. In 2011, in Embrun, Ontario, near Ottawa, some parents were displeased when a school replaced the Christmas concert it had held in previous years with a craft sale and winter concert scheduled for February.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://news.nationalpost.com/news/canada/ontario-school-replaces-christmas-concert-with-non-denominational-february-fest |title= Parents' Anger as Ontario School Replaces Christmas Concert with Non-Denominational February Fest |work= National Post |first= Matthew |last= Pearson |date= 1 December 2011 |accessdate= 25 December 2012}}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== In the United Kingdom there have been some controversies, one of the most famous being the temporary promotion of the phrase [[Winterval]] for a whole season of events (including Christmas festivities) by Birmingham City Council in the late 1990s. This remains a controversial example of "Christmas controversy", with critics attacking the use of the word "Winterval" as being ''political correctness gone mad'', accusing council officials of trying to take the Christ out of Christmas.<ref name="BBC Winterval">{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/210672.stm |title= Winterval Gets Frosty Reception |date= 9 November 1998 |publisher= BBC News |accessdate= 23 December 2011}}</ref> The council responded to the criticism by stating that Christmas-related words and symbols were prominent in its publicity material: ''"...there was a banner saying Merry Christmas across the front of the council house, Christmas lights, Christmas trees in the main civil squares, regular carol-singing sessions by school choirs, and the Lord Mayor sent a Christmas card with a traditional Christmas scene wishing everyone a Merry Christmas"...''<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2006/dec/08/religion.communities |title= The Phoney War on Christmas |work= The Guardian |first= Oliver |last= Burkeman |date= 7 December 2006 |accessdate= 25 December 2012 |location= London}}</ref>
In November 2009 the city council of Dundee was accused of banning Christmas because it promoted its celebrations as the Winter Night Light festival, initially with no specific references to Christianity. Local church leaders were invited to participate in the event, and they did.<ref>{{cite news |first= April |last= Mitchinson |url= http://www.pressandjournal.co.uk/Article.aspx/1502592?UserKey= |title= Differences Set Aside for Winter Night Light Festival in Dundee |work= The Press and Journal |location= Aberdeen |date= 29 November 2009 |accessdate= 29 November 2009}}</ref>
Due to the changing religious landscape of the UK, Christmas cards featuring religious imagery, such as the [[Nativity scene]] or the Virgin and Child, have become less common in major retailers. However, they are still readily available from smaller shops, or those linked to church groups and charities. The [[Church of England]] complained in 2004 when religious images were removed from the annual tradition of special [[postage stamps]] around Christmas.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-491954/Hark-herald-angels-years-Christmas-stamps.html |location= London |work= The Daily Mail |title= Hark, the Herald Angels Are Back on This Year's Christmas Stamps |date= 6 November 2007}}</ref>
===South Africa=== The Christian holidays of [[Christmas Day]] and [[Good Friday]] remained in secular [[post-apartheid South Africa]]'s [[public holidays in South Africa|calendar of public holidays]]. The [[Commission for the Promotion and Protection of the Rights of Cultural, Religious and Linguistic Communities]] (CRL Rights Commission), a [[chapter nine institution]] established in 2004, held countrywide consultative public hearings in June and July 2012 to assess the need for a review of public holidays following the receipt of complaints from minority groups about unfair discrimination. The CRL Rights Commission stated that they would submit their recommendations to the [[Department of Home Affairs (South Africa)|Department of Home Affairs]], the [[Department of Labour (South Africa)|Department of Labour]], various Portfolio Committees and the [[President of South Africa|Office of the Presidency]] by October 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=CRL Rights Commission Continues with the Consultative Community Hearings on the Possible Review of Public Holidays |url=http://www.info.gov.za/speech/DynamicAction?pageid=461&sid=28605&tid=73934 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130310081324/http://www.info.gov.za/speech/DynamicAction?pageid=461&sid=28605&tid=73934 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=10 March 2013 |publisher=info.gov.za |date=26 June 2012 |accessdate=2 November 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title= Fight over Religious Holidays |url= http://www.crlcommission.org.za/fightoverholidays.php |publisher= CRL Rights Commission |accessdate= 2 November 2012 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20141018121257/http://www.crlcommission.org.za/fightoverholidays.php |archivedate= 18 October 2014 |df= dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title= Hands off Christmas, Protesters Say |url= http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Hands-off-Christmas-protesters-say-20121110 |publisher= [[News24]] |date= 10 November 2012 |accessdate= 10 November 2012}}</ref> The CRL Rights Commission published its recommendations on 17 April 2013, including the scrapping of some existing public holidays to free up days for some non-Christian religious public holidays.<ref>{{cite web |title= Recommendations: Public Holidays vs Religious/Cultural Holydays |url= http://www.crlcommission.org.za/icr_docs/public_holidays_recomendations.pdf |publisher= CRL Rights Commission |accessdate= 23 April 2013 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130513085841/http://www.crlcommission.org.za/icr_docs/public_holidays_recomendations.pdf |archivedate= 13 May 2013 |df= dmy-all }}<!--Publication date per link to document from home page: "Investigation and Conflict Resolution Reports: The ICR Reports were launched on Wednesday 17 April 2013"--></ref><ref>{{cite news |title= Public Holidays Scrutinised |type= Video |url= http://www.enca.com/south-africa-life/your-public-holidays-religiuos |accessdate= 30 April 2013 |newspaper= eNCA |date= 29 April 2013}}</ref>
===Norway=== The common practice of schoolchildren visiting local churches for Christmas services in December is opposed by the [[Norwegian Humanist Association]], the [[Children's Ombudsman]] and by the [[Union of Education Norway|Union of Education]].<ref name=vl/> There have been several local controversies over the issue. The political parties have mostly been in favor of this being decided by the schools themselves, but the government has underlined that schools who participate in Christmas services must offer an alternative for pupils who don’t want to attend and that services must not take place on the day that marks the closing of schools before the Christmas holiday. The [[Solberg's Cabinet]] says in its government declaration that it looks positively upon schools taking part in services in churches before religious holidays.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.dagen.no/2013/10/09/meninger/hoyre/kirkeasyl/siv_jensen/172635 |title= Skolegudstjenester og kirkeasyl] |work=Dagen |access-date= 12 December 2013 |language= no}}</ref>
According to a 2013 poll by Norstat for ''[[Vårt Land (Norwegian newspaper)|Vårt Land]]'', 68% of Norwegians support having school-arranged Christmas servicess while 14% are opposed. 17% do not hold any opinion on the issue.<ref name=vl>{{cite news |first1= Turid |last1= Sylte |first2= Eirik |last2= Omvik |last-author-amp= yes |date= 12 December 2013 |url= http://www.vl.no/samfunn/7-av-10-vil-ha-skolegudstjenester/ |title= 7 av 10 vil ha skolegudstjenester |trans-title= 7 out of 10 will have school worship |work= [[Vårt Land (Norwegian newspaper)|Vårt Land]] |access-date= 12 December 2013 |language= no |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://archive.is/20131212125639/http://www.vl.no/samfunn/7-av-10-vil-ha-skolegudstjenester/ |archivedate= 12 December 2013 |df= dmy-all }}</ref>
===Sweden=== A school law in 2011, which explicitly stated that public schools should be non-confessional, led to debate over what this meant for the tradition that schools gather in churches in December to celebrate Advent, [[Saint Lucy's Day|Lucia]] or Christmas. 80,000 Swedes signed a 2012 protest letter (''Adventsuppropet'') initiated by the newspaper ''[[Dagen (Swedish newspaper)|Dagen]]'' to Minister for Education [[Jan Björklund]], in which they demanded that school visits to churches should still be allowed to include religious rituals.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.kyrkanstidning.se/inrikes/upprop-skolavslutningar-overlamnat-till-utbildningsministern |title= Upprop för skolavslutningar överlämnat till utbildningsministern |work= Kyrkans Tidning |access-date= 12 December 2013 |language= sv}}</ref> The minister clarified that church visits before Christmas might include singing of Christmas hymns and a priest talking about the Christmas gospel while on the other side common prayers and reading a [[Confession of Faith]] would violate the law.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.folkpartiet.se/jan-bjorklund/nyhetsbrev/?nid=215623 |title= Ja till skolavslutning i kyrkan |work= Folkpartiet.se |date= 27 November 2012 |access-date= 12 December 2013 |language= sv}}</ref>
In 2012, [[Sveriges Radio]] reported that about one in six schools had changed the way they mark Christmas traditions as a result of the new law.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=3993&artikel=5372806 |title= Var sjätte skola har bytt jultraditioner efter ny lag |publisher= Sveriges Radio |date= 7 December 2012 |access-date= 12 December 2013 |language= sv}}</ref>
===Christmas tree=== [[File:Lowes holiday.jpg|thumb|In 2007, U.S. hardware store chain [[Lowe's]] published a catalog that accidentally referred to Christmas trees as "Family trees"]] <!-- [[Holiday tree]] redirects to this exact section title --> Since the 1980s,<ref>[http://www.firstamendmentcenter.org/news.aspx?id=19377 Wisconsin Lawmaker Seeks to Ax State's 'Holiday' Tree] {{webarchive|url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20080725133336/http://www.firstamendmentcenter.org/news.aspx?id=19377 |date=25 July 2008 }} - Associated Press article</ref> there have been several instances in both the United States and Canada when official public mentions and references to [[Christmas tree]]s were renamed to "holiday trees". Reaction to such renamings has been mixed.
One of the most prominent Christmas tree controversies came in 2005, when the city of Boston labeled their official decorated tree as a holiday tree, and the subsequent response from the Nova Scotian tree farmer who donated the tree was that he would rather have put the tree in a wood chipper than have it named a "holiday" tree.<ref name="USAToday" />
In 2009 in West Jerusalem, the Lobby for Jewish Values, with support of the Jerusalem [[Chief Rabbinate of Israel|Rabbinate]], handed out fliers condemning Christmas and called for a boycott of "restaurants and hotels that sell or put up Christmas trees and other 'foolish' Christian symbols".<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.haaretz.com/news/rabbis-versus-christmas-religious-rivalry-in-jerusalem-benefits-no-one-1.1917 |title= Rabbis Versus Christmas: Religious Rivalry in Jerusalem Benefits No One |work= Haaretz |date= 17 December 2009 |first= Morten |last= Berthelsen |accessdate= 25 December 2012}}</ref>
The [[Brussels Christmas tree]] in the Belgian capital sparked controversy in December 2012, as it was part of renaming the Christmas Market as "Winter Pleasures".<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/brussels-modern-art-christmas-tree-triggers-outcry-tensions-petition/article6408631/ |location= Toronto |work= The Globe and Mail |title= Brussels' Modern-Art Christmas 'Tree' Triggers Outcry, Tensions, Petition |date= 26 December 2012}}</ref> Local opposition saw it as appeasement of the Muslim minority in the city.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-20302574 |publisher= BBC News |title= Abstract Christmas Tree Sparks Protests in Brussels |date= 1 December 2012}}</ref>
====Resurgence of "Christmas tree"==== Efforts have also been made to rename official public holiday trees back to Christmas trees. In 2002, a bill was introduced in the California Senate to rename the State Holiday Tree the California State Christmas Tree;<ref>{{cite web |url= http://sfatheists.blogspot.com/2002/06/letter-to-committee-on-governmental.html |title= Letter to the Committee on Governmental Organization RE: SB 1577 Redesignation of State Holiday Tree as a Christmas Tree |publisher= sfatheists.blogspot.com |date= 18 June 2002 |first= Dave |last= Kong |accessdate= 25 December 2012}}{{self-published source|date= December 2015}}</ref> while this measure did not pass, at the official lighting of the tree on 4 December 2007, California Governor [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] referred to the tree as a Christmas tree in his remarks and in the press release his office issued after the ceremony.<ref>{{cite press release |url= http://gov.ca.gov/news.php?id=8222 |title= Governor and First Lady Celebrate 76th Annual Christmas Tree Lighting |publisher= Office of the Governor of California |accessdate= 25 December 2012}}</ref> Schwarzenegger had previously ended the secular practice of calling it a "holiday tree" in 2004 during the 73rd annual lighting. The name change was in honor of the late Senator William "Pete" Knight. Schwarzenegger said at Knight's funeral that he would change the name back to Christmas tree. Knight had lobbied unsuccessfully to change the name after Governor Davis decided to call it a holiday tree.<ref>{{cite news |title= Governor Plugs Christmas Back into State Tree-Lighting Ceremony |url= https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=yatAAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_CAGAAAAIBAJ&pg=6917,3847433&dq=schwarzenegger+holiday-tree&hl=en |accessdate= 26 December 2012 |newspaper= Lodl News Sentinel |date= 3 December 2004 |page= 5 |agency= [[Associated Press]] |via= [[Google News]] }}</ref>
The Michigan Senate had a debate in 2005 over whether the decorated tree in front of the Michigan Capitol would continue to be called a holiday tree (as it had been since the early 1990s) or named a Christmas tree. The question was revisited in 2006, when the bipartisan Michigan Capitol Committee voted unanimously to use the term Christmas tree.<ref>{{cite news |title= Mich. Capitol Conifer Re-Christened 'Christmas Tree' |url= http://www.firstamendmentcenter.org/mich-capitol-conifer-re-christened-christmas-tree |accessdate= 29 December 2012 |publisher= FirstAmendmentCenter.org |date= 30 November 2006 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://swap.stanford.edu/20140329054451/http://www.firstamendmentcenter.org/mich-capitol-conifer-re-christened-christmas-tree |archivedate= 29 March 2014 |df= dmy-all }}</ref> And in 2007, Wisconsin lawmakers considered whether to rename the tree in the Wisconsin Capitol rotunda, a holiday tree since 1985, the Wisconsin State Christmas Tree.<ref>{{cite news |title= Bah Humbug Bill to Rechristen Holiday Tree Fizzles on Way to Senate |url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-172373116.html |accessdate= 29 December 2012 |newspaper= The Capital Times |first= Scott |last= Bauer |date= 12 December 2007 |agency= Association Press |location= Madison, WI |via= [[HighBeam Research]] |subscription= yes}}</ref>
===Rejection among certain groups=== ====Atheism==== Under the [[state atheism]] of the former Eastern Bloc, Christmas was banned, along with other Christian holidays.<ref name="Luzer2013">{{cite web |last1=Luzer |first1=Daniel |title=What a Real War on Christmas Looks Like |url=https://psmag.com/social-justice/whats-real-war-christmas-look-like-70524 |publisher=[[Pacific Standard]] |date=26 November 2013|quote=In 1925, Christmas was effectively banned under the officially atheist Soviets, and was not to return to Russian lands until 1992. ... The state prohibited people from selling Christmas trees. There were even festivals, organized by the League of Militant Atheists, specifically to denigrate religious holidays. Their carnivals were inspired by similar events staged by activists after the French Revolution. From 1923 to 1924 and then again from 1929 to 1930 the "Komsomol Christmases" and Easters were basically holiday celebrations of atheism.}}</ref> The [[League of Militant Atheists]] organized alternate festivals "specifically to denigrate religious holidays" in the USSR.<ref name="Luzer2013"/> In the United States, some atheists may choose to celebrate Christmas fully, while others celebrate only portions of the holiday, and others reject it completely.<ref name="Cline2018">{{cite web |last1=Cline |first1=Austin |title=Should Atheists Ignore Christmas or Celebrate It? |url=https://www.thoughtco.com/should-atheists-ignore-christmas-or-celebrate-249570 |website=ThoughtCo |publisher=[[Dotdash]]|date=15 July 2018|quote=There is a debate among atheists about whether they should celebrate Christmas or not. Some do so because they aren’t "out" as atheists. Some do so in order not to rock the boat among religious family members. Some do so because they always have and don’t want to change — or simply enjoy the holiday. Others argue that it should be replaced by a more secular holiday, and still others suggest that all such holidays should be ignored by atheists.}}</ref> Some atheist groups who oppose the celebration of Christmas have established alternate celebrations to the Christian observance of Christmas, such as [[HumanLight]].<ref name="Cline2018"/>
====Islam==== The celebration of Christmas has occasionally been criticized in countries which are predominantly [[Muslim]].{{citation needed|date=December 2015}} Turkey has adopted a secular version of Christmas and a Santa Claus figure named ''Noel Baba'' (from the French [[Père Noël]]). During the 2013 holiday season, a Muslim youth group launched an anti-Santa Claus campaign, protesting against the celebration of Christmas in the country.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://en.trend.az/world/turkey/2224955.html|title=Anti-Santa campaigns heat up in Turkey as Christmas arrives|date=25 December 2013|work=Trend News Agency|accessdate=14 November 2018|}}</ref> In December 2015, political and religious activists organized protests against the growing influence of Christmas and Santa Claus in Turkish society.<ref>{{Cite web |title= Turks Protest Against 'Creeping Christmas' |work= Middleeasteye.net |accessdate= 26 December 2015 |date= 23 December 2015 |url= http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/turkey-christmas-not-happy-1848737240}}</ref>
====Restorationist Movement==== Some Churches, sects, and communities of the [[Restoration Movement]] reject the observance of Christmas for theological reasons; these include [[Jehovah's Witnesses]],<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.jw.org/en/jehovahs-witnesses/faq/why-not-celebrate-christmas/.htm |title=Jehovah's Witness on Christmas |publisher= www.jw.org |accessdate= 1 January 2013}}</ref>; [[Armstrongism|Armstrongites]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E3___tE12R0</ref> the [[True Jesus Church]], [[General Conference of the Church of God (Seventh-Day)|Church of God (7th-Day)]], the [[Iglesia ni Cristo]], the [[Christian Congregation in Brazil]], the [[Christian Congregation in the United States]], the [[Churches of Christ]], as well as certain [[Reformed churches|reformed]] and [[fundamentalism|fundamentalist]] churches of various persuasions, including some [[Independent Baptists]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://libcfl.com/articles/becker2.htm|title=The Truth about Christmas|first=Greg|last=Wilson|publisher=}}</ref> and [[Oneness Pentecostalism|Oneness Pentecostals]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prime.org/|title=Jesus Name Apostolic Holiness Church - Oneness Pentecostal|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.tjc.org/showArticle.aspx?aid=7219 |title= Is Christmas Biblical? |publisher= tjc.org |accessdate= 1 January 2013 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20130722145542/http://www.tjc.org/showArticle.aspx?aid=7219 |archive-date= 22 July 2013 |dead-url= yes |df= dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.churchofgod-7thday.org/FAQs.html |title= Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) |publisher= churchofgod-7thday.org |accessdate= 1 January 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.iglesianicristowebsite.com/Pages/7-faq-answers.html |title= All About Iglesia ni Cristo: Frequently Asked Questions |publisher= iglesianicristowebsite.com |accessdate=1 January 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.christianchronicle.org/article/christ-in-christmas-churches-of-christ-and-the-holiday-season?A=SearchResult&SearchID=4375144&ObjectID=4364696&ObjectType=35|title= 'Christ' in Christmas?: Churches of Christ and the Holiday Season |work= [[Christian Chronicle]] |accessdate= 22 January 2017}}</ref>
==Xmas== The December 1957 ''News and Views'' published by the [[Church League of America]], a conservative organization co-founded in 1937 by George Washington Robnett,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://libweb.uoregon.edu/speccoll/guides/conservative.html |title= Subject Guide to Conservative and Libertarian Materials, in Manuscript Collections |publisher= University of Oregon}}</ref> attacked the use of [[Xmas]] in an article titled "X=The Unknown Quantity". The claims were picked up later by [[Gerald L. K. Smith]], who in December 1966 claimed that Xmas was a "blasphemous omission of the name of Christ" and that "'X' is referred to as being symbolical of the unknown quantity." Smith further argued that Jews introduced Santa Claus to suppress the New Testament accounts of Jesus, and that the United Nations, at the behest of "world Jewry", had "outlawed the name of Christ".<ref>{{cite book |author-link= Morris Kominsky |last= Kominsky |first= Morris |year= 1970 |title= The Hoaxers: Plain Liars, Fancy Liars and Damned Liars |pages= 137–138 |isbn= 0-8283-1288-5}}{{full citation needed|date=December 2015}}</ref> There is, however, a well documented history of use of ''Χ'' (actually a [[Chi (letter)|chi]]) as an abbreviation for "Christ" (Χριστός) and possibly also a symbol of the cross.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ancient-symbols.com/christian_symbols.html |title= Christian Symbols and Their Descriptions |publisher= Ancient-symbols.com |date= |accessdate= 8 December 2008}}{{unreliable source?|date= December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://tlc.howstuffworks.com/family/xmas.htm |publisher= tlc.howstuffworks.com |title= Why Is There a Controversy Surrounding the Word 'Xmas'? |accessdate= 25 December 2012}}{{unreliable source?|date= December 2015}}</ref> The abbreviation appears on many Orthodox Christian religious icons.
==See also== {{Portal|Christmas|Christianity}} * [[Culture war]] * [[Santa Claus#Calvinist and Puritan opposition|Santa Claus—Calvinist and Puritan opposition]] * [[Christian persecution complex]]
