{{Infobox book | name = Modern Paganism in World Cultures: Comparative Perspectives | image = Modern Paganism in World Cultures.jpg | caption = The cover of the book. | author = Michael F. Strmiska (editor) | country = United States | language = English | subject = [[Religious studies]]
[[Pagan studies]] | publisher = [[ABC-CLIO]] | release_date = 2005 | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover]]) | pages = 382 | isbn = 978-1-85109-608-4 | oclc = }} '''''Modern Paganism in World Cultures: Comparative Perspectives''''' is an academic anthology edited by the American [[religious studies]] scholar Michael F. Strmiska which was published by [[ABC-CLIO]] in 2005. Containing eight separate papers produced by various scholars working in the field of [[Pagan studies]], the book examines different forms of [[Paganism (contemporary)|contemporary Paganism]] as practiced in Europe and North America. ''Modern Paganism in World Cultures'' was published as a part of ABC-CLIO's series of books entitled 'Religion in Contemporary Cultures', in which other volumes were dedicated to religious movements like [[Buddhism]] and [[Islam]]. Edited by Strmiska, then a lecturer at [[Central Connecticut State University]] in [[New Britain, Connecticut|New Britain]], [[Connecticut]], the volume contained contributions from scholars from a variety of academic backgrounds, some of whom were practicing Pagans themselves. In her paper, the American folklorist [[Sabina Magliocco]] discussed "ethnic ambivalence" amongst the [[Italian American]] community in regards to the relationship between [[Stregheria]] and [[Wicca]], whilst the Irish folklorist Jenny Butler dealt with the place of contemporary [[Neo-Druidism|Druidry]] in Ireland. In a paper co-written by Strmiska and Icelandic anthropologist Baldur A. Sigurvinsson, the religion of [[Asatru]] in both [[Iceland]] and the United States was compared, which is followed by a piece by British anthropologist Jenny Blain looking at the way in which British Heathens viewed sacred sites. The sixth paper, written by environmental studies scholar Adrian Ivakhiv, looked at Paganism in [[Ukraine]], whilst the seventh, co-written once more by Strmiska, this time with humanities scholar Vilius Rudra Dundzila, looked at [[Romuva (religion)|Romuva]] in both [[Lithuania]] and the U.S. The final paper, produced by military veteran Stephanie Urquhart, looked at the acceptance of Pagans in the U.S. military. Academic reviews were largely positive, praising the various papers for expanding the knowledge of Pagan studies by focusing on less well known religions like Romuva and Asatru rather than Wicca, the dominant Pagan faith to which the majority of literature in the field of Pagan studies had been devoted up until that point. ==Background== Michael Strmiska had gained an MA in the Religions of India from the [[University of Wisconsin-Madison]] before going on to gain a PhD in Religious Studies from [[Boston University]]. Proceeding to teach Comparative Religion and World History, he worked at universities in Lithuania, the United States and Japan, and at the time of ''Modern Paganism in World Cultures''' publication was lecturing in World History at [[Central Connecticut State University]].[[#Str(ed)05|Strmiska (ed.) 2005]]. p. viii. Strmiska decided to allow the contributing authors to choose whether they would use the term "Pagan" or "Neopagan" in reference to the contemporary religious movements, arguing that they should do so according to which term "is best suited to their topics."[[#Str05|Strmiska 2005]]. p. 10. ==Synopsis== ===Strmiska's "Comparative Perspectives"=== In his opening chapter, which shares its name with the book, Michael Strmiska discusses the significance of Paganism to the contemporary world, although notes that this volume deals specifically with the movement in Europe and North America, "in the belief that this regional focus provides a coherent frame of discussion with a number of intriguing commonalities and contrasts without degenerating into a global encyclopaedia."[[#Str05|Strmiska 2005]]. p. 1. Noting that earlier studies of Pagan studies had focused primarily on the religion of Wicca and on the Pagan movement in the U.S. and U.K., Strmiska explained that in this volume, he had widened the geographical scope by focusing on forms of Paganism other than Wicca and on the movement in other parts of Europe and North America, such as in Canada, Ireland and Iceland.[[#Str05|Strmiska 2005]]. p. 2. Proceeding to look at the various definitions of the terms "Pagan" and "Neopagan", Strmiska discusses why some contemporary westerners choose to adopt such terms when they have a pejorative meaning in western culture, concluding that not only was it an "appealing marker" in expressing their non-Christian beliefs, but that it also served to give them a sense of connection to ancient pre-Christian peoples and as "a deliberate act of defiance" against a Christian-dominated culture.[[#Str05|Strmiska 2005]]. pp. 4-10. ===Magliocco's "Italian American Stregheria and Wicca"=== The second paper in the volume was provided by the American folklorist [[Sabina Magliocco]], who had studied the Pagan community in the U.S. for a number of years, resulting in the publication of two books, ''Neo-pagan Sacred Art and Altars: Making Things Work'' (2002) and ''[[Witching Culture|Witching Culture: Folklore and Neo-paganism in America]]'' (2004).[[#Mag02|Maglicco 2002]] and [[#Mag04|Magliocco 2004]]. ===Butler's "Druidry in Contemporary Ireland"=== [[Image:Druids, in the early morning glow of the sun.jpg|thumb|250px|A group of Druids, members of the new religious movement which Jenny Butler studied.]] In the book's third paper, the Irish folklorist [http://www.drjennybutler.com Jenny Butler], who was then studying for a PhD on Paganism in Ireland at the Department of Folklore and Ethnology at [[University College Cork]] and now based at the [http://www.ucc.ie/en/religion// UCC's Department of Study of Religions],[[#Str(ed)05|Strmiska (ed.) 2005]]. p. vii. looked at the role of contemporary Druidry in the country. ===Strmiska and Sigurvinsson's "Asatru"=== ===Blain's "Heathenry, the Past, and Sacred Sites in Today's Britain"=== ===Ivakhiv'a "The Revival of Ukrainian Native Faith"=== ===Strmiska and Dundzila's "Romuva"=== [[File:Romuvan ceremony (1).PNG|thumb|right|Romuvan priestess leading ritual.]] ===Urquhart's "Onward Pagan Soldiers"=== ==Reception and recognition== ===Academic reviews=== In a highly positive review published in ''[[The Pomegranate: The International Journal of Pagan Studies]]'', the religious studies scholar Nikki Bado-Fralick of [[Iowa State University]] described ''Modern Paganism in World Cultures'' as an "engaging and insightful look into several under-reported forms of European and North American Contemporary Paganism". Considering it to be "extremely well written, accessible, and organized", Bado-Fralick felt that the work made "a delightful addition to the growing body of first-rate scholarship on Contemporary Paganism." Praising the use of maps in the book, she felt however that "I found myself wishing for more detailed maps when authors referred to groups from specific counties or regional areas." Ultimately, Bado-Fralick considered the work to be "securely placed to become a mainstay of the Pagan scholar's bookshelf."[[#Bad06|Bado-Fralick 2006]]. The anthology was also reviewed by Robert Ellwood of the [[University of Southern California]] for the ''[[Nova Religio]]'' journal, who considered it notable that it focused primarily on non-Wiccan variants of Paganism. Considering the work to be a "substantial contribution" to contemporary religious studies, he notes that the price of the volume will put many individuals off of purchasing it, but that he hoped most major libraries would acquire a copy.[[#Ell07|Ellwood 2007]]. ==References== ===Footnotes=== {{reflist|20em}} ===Bibliography=== ;Academic sources {{refbegin}} * {{cite book |title= Neo-pagan Sacred Art and Altars: Making Things Work |last=Magliocco |first=Sabina |authorlink=Sabina Magliocco |year= 2002|publisher= University Press of Mississippi|location= |isbn=978-1-57806-391-8 |nopp=|ref=Mag02}} * {{cite book |title= Witching Culture: Folklore and Neo-paganism in America |last=Magliocco |first=Sabina |authorlink=Sabina Magliocco |year= 2004|publisher= University of Pennsylvania Press|location= Philadelphia|isbn=978-0-8122-3803-7 |nopp=|ref=Mag04}} * {{Cite news|title=Modern Paganism in World Cultures: Comparative Perspectives |last=Strmiska |first=Michael F. |year=2005 |journal=Modern Paganism in World Cultures: Comparative Perspectives |editors=Michael F. Strmiska (ed.) |publisher=ABC-CLIO |location=Santa Barbara, CAL. |isbn=978-1-85109-608-4 |pages=1–53 |ref=Str05}} {{refend}} ;Academic reviews {{Refbegin}} * {{Cite news|title=Review of ''Modern Paganism in World Cultures'' |last=Ellwood |first=Robert |year=2007 |journal=Nova Religio: The Journal of Alternative and Emergent Religions |volume=11 |issue=2 |location= |publisher=University of California Press |pages=131–132 |jstor=10.1525/nr.2007.11.2.131 .|ref=Ell07}} * {{Cite news|title=Review of ''Modern Paganism in World Cultures'' |last=Bado-Fralick |first=Nikki |year=2006 |journal=The Pomegranate: The International Journal of Pagan Studies |volume=8 |issue=2 |location= |publisher=Equinox |pages=250–251 |ref=Fra06}} {{refend}} {{Pagan studies}} [[Category:2005 books]] [[Category:Religious studies books]] [[Category:Pagan studies books]] [[Category:Neopaganism in the United States]]

'''Muṣaṣir''' Assyrian {{lang|akk-Latn|<sup>KUR</sup>Mu-ṣa-ṣir}} and variants, including Mutsatsir, [[Akkadian language|Akkadian]] for ''Exit of the Serpent/Snake'' ), in [[Urartian language|Urartian]] '''Ardini''' was an ancient city of [[Urartu]], attested in Assyrian sources of the 9th and 8th centuries BC.
[[File:Sandstone statue of a man or deity. The statue belonged to the Musasir Kingdom. Urartian period, 1st millennium BCE. Precise provenance of excavation is unknown. Erbil Civilization Museum, Iraqi Kurdistan.jpg|thumb|Sandstone statue of a man or deity. The statue belonged to the Musasir Kingdom. Urartian period, 1st millennium BCE. Precise provenance of excavation is unknown. Erbil Civilization Museum, Iraqi Kurdistan.]]
It was acquired by the Urartian King [[Ishpuinis of Urartu|Ishpuini]] ca. 800 BC (see the [[Kelashin Stele]]). The city's tutelary deity was [[Khaldi (god)|<sup>d</sup>Ḫaldi]]. The name Musasir in Akkadian means ''exit of the serpent''.
The city's location is not known with certainty, although there are a number of hypotheses, all in the general area of {{Coord|36|N|46|E|}}, in the [[Zagros]] south of [[Lake Urmia]]. [[François Thureau-Dangin]] tentatively located it at [[Mudjesir]], 10 km west of [[Topzawa]]. Reza Heidari, an archaeologist of the "Cultural Heritage and Tourism Organization" of Iran's [[West Azarbaijan Province]] claims [[Rabat Tepe]] near [[Sardasht, West Azerbaijan|Sardasht]], [[Iran]] as the location of Muṣaṣir.<ref>[http://www.archaeologynews.org/link.asp?ID=46900 Archaeologynews.org] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716104247/http://www.archaeologynews.org/link.asp?ID=46900 |date=2011-07-16 }}</ref> Lynch claimed that it was close to the modern town of [[Rowanduz]] in [[Iraqi Kurdistan]] <ref>{{cite web |title= Armenia: travels and studies |year=1901 |last=Lynch |first=H.F.B. |url=https://archive.org/stream/armeniatravelsst02lync/armeniatravelsst02lync_djvu.txt |accessdate=2009-09-08}}</ref>
==Temple== The '''Musasir temple''', built in 825 BC, was an important temple in Musasir, the holy city of [[Urartu]]. The Temple at Musasir appears in an [[Assyria]]n bas-relief which adorned the palace of [[Sargon II|King Sargon II]] at [[Dur-Sharrukin|Khorsabad]], to commemorate his victory over "the seven kings of Urartu" in 714 BC.<ref>{{Garbis Armen 1992|page=16-19}}</ref>
(1802 - 1870) During the early 1850s, the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|British]] [[Assyria]]n Excavation Fund entered the field under [[William Kennett Loftus]] and many antiquities and accurate drawings of wall sculptures were apportioned between the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|British]] Museum and the Louvre. However, a convoy of antiquities was attacked by [[Arab]] robbers while being shipped down the [[Tigris River]], and today lies buried somewhere in the bed of that river. That particular bas-relief was copied at its original location in the palace onto a drawing by Eugene Flandin(2) as Botta's chief artist.<ref name="ByMark">Paul-Emile Botta's Excavations of 1843 By Mark A. Kalustian</ref>
During this period of Assyrian campaigns, the northern Araratian regions were governed by [[Sarduri II|Sarduri]]-and later by his son [[Rusa I|Rusa]] ([[Armenian language|Armenian]]: Հրաչյա ''Hrachya'', according to [[Moses of Chorene|Movses Khorenatsi]]) with the capital at [[Tushpa]] ([[Classical Armenian]]: Տոսպ ''Tosp'') located near the great city and the capital of the mighty Kingdom of Urartu, [[Van, Turkey|Van]] (Biaina) on the eastern shore of [[Lake Van]]. Sarduri placed [[Urzana]] as the governor of the spiritual center of Urartu, the Temple of [[Khaldi (god)|Khaldi]] -- Musasir Ardini.<ref name="ByMark" />
== Potential locations == *[[Altintepe]]: Since 1959, the Historical Society and the Department of Antiquities have conducted excavations in the Yerznka area, west of Karin. Here at Altintepe was revealed an [[Urartu|Urartian]] temple and other monuments. Only the foundations of the temple are in view. Obviously this is not the temple of Musasir as it is located far away from the concerned area.<ref>The Armenian Review. June 1980, pp. 214-215 with illustration. An Armenian Cylinder, by Mark A. Kalustian.</ref>
*[[Rabat Tepe]]: Recently a site excavated in Iran, which is called Rabat Tepe and located at the southwestern side of Lake Urmia, was identified as Musasir.
*At a site called Gund-i Topzawa north of [[Erbil]] in [[Iraqi Kurdistan]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Jarus|first1=Owen|title=Remains of Long-Lost Temple Discovered in Iraq|url=https://www.livescience.com/46674-remains-of-long-lost-temple-discovered-in-iraq.html|accessdate=24 September 2017|work=Live Science|date=7 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Lydia|title=Iraqi Villagers Accidentally Find Iron Age 'Long-Lost Temple of Musasir' Dedicated to Urartian God|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/iraqi-villagers-accidentally-find-iron-age-long-lost-temple-musasir-dedicated-urartian-god-1455807|accessdate=24 September 2017|work=International Business Times UK|date=8 July 2014|language=en}}</ref>

The '''National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) for Fiscal Year 2012'''<ref>112th Congress, 1st Session, H1540CR.HSE: [http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/BILLS-112hr1540enr/pdf/BILLS-112hr1540enr.pdf "National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2012."]</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=H.R. 1540 (112th): National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2012|url=https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/112/hr1540|publisher=govtrack.us|accessdate=26 July 2014}}</ref> ({{USPL|112|81}}) is a [[United States federal law]] which besides other provisions specifies the budget and expenditures of the [[United States Department of Defense]]. The bill passed the U.S. House on December 14, 2011, the U.S. Senate on December 15, 2011, and was signed into [[United States]] law on December 31, 2011, by [[President of the United States|President]] [[Barack Obama]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/obama-signs-defense-bill-pledges-to-maintain-legal-rights-of-terror-suspects/2011/12/31/gIQATzbkSP_story.html | title=Obama signs defense bill, pledges to maintain legal rights of terror suspects | publisher=Washington Post | accessdate=December 31, 2011 | first=David | last=Nakamura | date=2 January 2012 }}</ref><ref name="aclu1">{{cite web|url=https://www.aclu.org/national-security/president-obama-signs-indefinite-detention-bill-law |title=Obama Signs NDAA |publisher= ACLU |date=30 November 2011 |accessdate=2011-12-31 }}</ref>
The Act authorizes $662 billion in funding, among other things "for the defense of the United States and its interests abroad".<ref>Wolverton, J., "Obama Signs National Defense Authorization Act into Law," ''[[The New American]], [http://www.thenewamerican.com/usnews/constitution/item/8141-obama-signs-national-defense-authorization-act-into-law].</ref> In a [[signing statement]], President Obama described the Act as addressing national security programs, Department of Defense [[health care prices in the United States|health care costs]], [[counter-terrorism]] within the United States and abroad, and military modernization.<ref>[http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2011/12/31/statement-president-hr-1540 “President Obama's signing statement”] , "White House Press Office", December 31, 2011</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/index.php?pid=98513&st=&st1=#axzz1iE5qy7a3|title=Barack Obama: Statement on Signing the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2012|publisher=John T. Woolley and Gerhard Peters, The American Presidency Project [online]|date=December 31, 2011|accessdate=2012-01-03}}</ref> The Act also imposes new economic sanctions against [[Iran]] (section 1245), commissions appraisals of the military capabilities of countries such as [[Iran]], [[China]], and [[Russia]],<ref>Sections 1232 and 1240.</ref> and refocuses the strategic goals of NATO towards "energy security".<ref>Section 1233 from H1540CR.HSE: [http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/BILLS-112hr1540enr/pdf/BILLS-112hr1540enr.pdf "National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2012."].</ref> The Act also increases pay and healthcare costs for military service members<ref name="Howell20110620" /> and gives governors the ability to request the help of military reservists in the event of a hurricane, earthquake, flood, terrorist attack, or other disaster.<ref>{{cite news|title=New US law lets reservists respond to disasters|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2012/08/30/new-fed-law-lets-reservists-respond-to-disasters/|work=Associated Press|publisher=Fox News|accessdate=7 September 2012|date=30 August 2012}}</ref>
The most controversial provisions to receive wide attention were contained in subsections 1021–1022 of Title X, Subtitle D, entitled "Counter-Terrorism", authorizing the indefinite military detention of persons the government suspects of involvement in terrorism, including U.S. citizens arrested on American soil. Although the White House<ref name="whitehouse1">{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/files/omb/legislative/sap/112/saps1867s_20111117.pdf|title=STATEMENT OF ADMINISTRATION POLICY|date=17 November 2011|publisher=|accessdate=2011-12-14}}</ref> and Senate sponsors<ref name="csmonitor1">{{cite news|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Justice/2011/1203/Guantanamo-for-US-citizens-Senate-bill-raises-questions|title=Guantánamo for US citizens? Senate bill raises questions|date=3 December 2011|work=The Christian Science Monitor|accessdate=December 18, 2011|author=Knickerbocker, Brad}}</ref> maintain that the [[Authorization for Use of Military Force Against Terrorists|Authorization for Use of Military Force]] (AUMF) already grants presidential authority for indefinite detention, the Act states that Congress "affirms" this authority and makes specific provisions as to the exercise of that authority.<ref>Khalek, Rania, [http://www.alternet.org/rights/153421/%27global_battlefield%27_provision_allowing_indefinite_detention_of_citizens_accused_of_terror_could_pass_this_week "Global Battlefield' Provision Allowing Indefinite Detention of Citizens Accused of Terror Could Pass This Week"], ''Alternet,'' December 13, 2011.</ref><ref>Library of Congress THOMAS. H.R. 1540 – National Defense Authorization Act for fiscal year 2012 [http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/z?c112:H.R.1540: Versions of H.R.1540].</ref> The detention provisions of the Act have received critical attention by, among others, the [[American Civil Liberties Union]] (ACLU), the Bill of Rights Defense Committee, and some media sources which are concerned about the scope of the President's authority, including contentions that those whom they claim may be held indefinitely could include U.S. citizens arrested on American soil, including arrests by members of the Armed Forces.<ref name="NDAA">{{Cite news|url=https://www.aclu.org/blog/national-security/senate-rejects-amendment-banning-indefinite-detention|title=Senate Rejects Amendment Banning Indefinite Detention|last=Khaki|first=Ateqah|date=November 29, 2011|work=[[ACLU]] Blog of Rights|publisher=American Civil Liberties Union}}</ref><ref name="Savage">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/02/us/senate-declines-to-resolve-issue-of-american-qaeda-suspects-arrested-in-us.html|title=Senate Declines to Clarify Rights of American Qaeda Suspects Arrested in U.S.|last=Savage|first=Charlie|date=December 1, 2011|work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref><ref>Carter, Tom [http://www.wsws.org/articles/2011/dec2011/sena-d02.shtml "US Senators back law authorizing indefinite military detention without trial or charge,"] ''[[World Socialist Web Site]]'', December 2, 2011.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opencongress.org/bill/112-h1540/|title=H.R.1540: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2012 – U.S. Congress|date=|publisher=OpenCongress|accessdate=2011-12-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opencongress.org/bill/112-s1867/|title=S.1867: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2012 – U.S. Congress|date=|publisher=OpenCongress|accessdate=2011-12-14}}</ref> The detention powers currently face [[#Legal challenges to indefinite detention|legal challenge]].
==Detention without trial: Section 1021== The detention sections of the NDAA begin by "affirm[ing]" that the authority of the President under the [[Authorization for Use of Military Force Against Terrorists]] (AUMF), a joint resolution passed in the immediate aftermath of the [[September 11 attacks|September 11, 2001 attacks]], includes the power to detain, via the [[United States Armed Forces|Armed Forces]], any person, including a [[Citizenship in the United States|U.S. citizen]],<ref name=csmonitor1 /><ref>{{cite web|last=Greenwald|first=Glenn|title=Three myths about the detention bill|url=http://www.salon.com/2011/12/16/three_myths_about_the_detention_bill/|publisher=[[Salon (website)]]|accessdate=16 November 2012|date=16 December 2012|quote=Section 1021, authorizes indefinite detention for the broad definition of "covered persons" […]. And that section does provide that "Nothing in this section shall be construed to affect existing law or authorities relating to the detention of United States citizens, lawful resident aliens of the United States, or any other persons who are captured or arrested in the United States." So that section contains a disclaimer regarding an intention to expand detention powers for U.S. citizens, but does so only for the powers vested by that specific section. More important, the exclusion appears to extend only to U.S. citizens "captured or arrested in the United States" — meaning that the powers of indefinite detention vested by that section apply to U.S. citizens captured anywhere abroad (there is some grammatical vagueness on this point, but at the very least, there is a viable argument that the detention power in this section applies to U.S. citizens captured abroad).}}</ref> "who was part of or substantially supported [[al-Qaeda]], the [[Taliban]], or associated forces that are engaged in hostilities against the United States or its coalition partners", and anyone who commits a "belligerent act" against the United States or its coalition allies in aid of such enemy forces, under the law of war, "without trial, until the end of the hostilities authorized by the [AUMF]". The text authorizes trial by [[military tribunal]], or "transfer to the custody or control of the person's country of origin", or transfer to "any other foreign country, or any other foreign entity".<ref>112th Congress, 1st Session, H1540CR.HSE: [http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/BILLS-112hr1540enr/pdf/BILLS-112hr1540enr.pdf "National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2012."] pp. 265–266.</ref>
Addressing previous conflicts with the [[Obama Administration]] regarding the wording of the Senate text, the Senate–House compromise text, in sub-section 1021(d), also affirms that nothing in the Act "is intended to limit or expand the authority of the President or the scope of the Authorization for Use of Military Force". The final version of the bill also provides, in sub-section(e), that "Nothing in this section shall be construed to affect existing law or authorities relating to the detention of United States citizens, lawful resident aliens of the United States, or any other persons who are captured or arrested in the United States". As reflected in Senate debate over the bill, there is a great deal of controversy over the status of existing law.<ref name="Savage"/>
An amendment to the Act that would have replaced current text with a requirement for executive clarification of detention authorities was rejected by the Senate.<ref>[https://www.aclu.org/national-security/senate-poised-pass-indefinite-detention-without-charge-or-trial "Senate Poised to Pass Indefinite Detention Without Charge or Trial"], ''[[American Civil Liberties Union]]'', December 1, 2011.</ref> According to Senator [[Carl Levin]], "the language which precluded the application of section 1031 to American Citizens was in the bill that we originally approved in the Armed Services Committee and the Administration asked us to remove the language which says that U.S. citizens and lawful residents would not be subject to this section".<ref>[http://www.c-spanvideo.org/program/302754-1 Senate Session – C-SPAN Video Library<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The Senator refers to section 1021 as "1031" because it was section 1031 at the time of his speaking.
==Requirement for military custody: Section 1022== [[File:Camp x-ray detainees.jpg|left|thumb|Detainees upon arrival at [[Camp X-Ray (Guantanamo)|Camp X-Ray]], January 2002. In May 2006, the UN Committee against Torture condemned prisoners' treatment at Guantánamo Bay, noting that indefinite detention constitutes per se a violation of the UN Convention Against Torture.]] All persons arrested and detained according to the provisions of section 1021, including those detained on U.S. soil, whether detained indefinitely or not, are required to be held by the [[United States Armed Forces]]. The law affords the option to have U.S. citizens detained by the armed forces but this requirement does not extend to them, as with foreign persons. Lawful resident aliens may or may not be required to be detained by the Armed Forces, "on the basis of conduct taking place within the United States".<ref>McGreal, Chris, "Military given go-ahead to detain US terrorist suspects without trial," ''[[The Guardian]]'', 14 December 2011: [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/dec/15/americans-face-guantanamo-detention-obama?newsfeed=true].</ref><ref>Greenwald, Glenn, "Obama to sign indefinite detention bill into law," ''[[Salon.com]]'', 14 December 2011: [http://www.salon.com/2011/12/15/obama_to_sign_indefinite_detention_bill_into_law/].</ref>
During debate on the senate floor, Levin stated that "Administration officials reviewed the draft language for this provision and recommended additional changes. We were able to accommodate those recommendations, except for the Administration request that the provision apply only to detainees captured overseas and there's a good reason for that. Even here, the difference is modest, because the provision already excludes all U.S. citizens. It also excludes lawful residents of United States, except to extent permitted by the constitution. The only covered persons left are those who are illegally in this country or on a tourist visa or other short-term basis. Contrary to some press statements, the detainee provisions in our bill do not include new authority for the permanent detention of suspected terrorists. Rather, the bill uses language provided by the Administration to codify existing authority that has been upheld in federal courts".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.c-spanvideo.org/program/302754-1|title=Senate Session Nov. 17, 2011|publisher=C-Span|accessdate=16 June 2012|date=17 November 2012}}</ref>
A Presidential Policy Directive entitled "Requirements of the National Defense Authorization Act"<ref>{{cite web|title=Presidential Policy Directive – Requirements of the National Defense Authorization Act|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2012/02/28/presidential-policy-directive-requirements-national-defense-authorizatio|publisher=The White House Office of the Press Secretary|accessdate=5 January 2013|date=28 February 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=PRESIDENTIAL POLICY DIRECTIVE/PPD-14|url=http://www.justice.gov/opa/documents/ppd-14.pdf|work=The White House|publisher=justice.gov|accessdate=5 January 2013|date=28 February 2012}}</ref> regarding the procedures for implementing §1022 of the NDAA was issued on February 28, 2012, by the White House.<ref name="TalfLeft20120228">{{cite web|title=Obama Issues Rules for Determining Civilian vs Military Custody of Detainees|url=http://www.talkleft.com/story/2012/2/28/195352/628|publisher=TalkLeft: The Politics Of Crime|accessdate=5 January 2013|author=Jeralyn|date=28 February 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=FACT SHEET: PROCEDURES IMPLEMENTING SECTION 1022 OF THE NATIONAL DEFENSE AUTHORIZATION ACT FOR FISCAL YEAR 2012|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/files/ndaa_fact_sheet.pdf|work=The White House|publisher=The White House|accessdate=5 January 2013|date=28 February 2012}}</ref> The directive consists of eleven pages of specific implementation procedures including defining scope and limitations. Judge Kathrine B. Forrest wrote in ''[[Hedges v. Obama]]'': "That directive provides specific guidance as to the 'Scope of Procedures and Standard for Covered Persons Determinations.' Specifically, it states that 'covered persons' applies only to a person who is not a citizen of the United States and who is a member or part of al-Qaeda or an associated force that acts in coordination with or pursuant to the direction of al-Qaeda; and "who participated in the course of planning or carrying out an attack or attempted attack against the United States or its coalition partners" (see p. 11–12).<ref>{{cite court |litigants=Hedges v. Obama |vol=12-cv-00331 |reporter=|author=Katherine B. Forrest |opinion= |pinpoint= |court=U.S. District Court, Southern District of New York (Manhattan) |date=May 16, 2012 |url=http://nysd.uscourts.gov/cases/show.php?db=special&id=174 |accessdate=May 29, 2012 |quote=}}</ref> Under procedures released by the White House the military custody requirement can be waived in a wide variety of cases.<ref name="TalfLeft20120228" /> Among the waiver possibilities are the following:<ref name="THP20130103">{{cite news|last=Reilly|first=Ryan J.|title=NDAA Signed Into Law By Obama Despite Guantanamo Veto Threat, Indefinite Detention Provisions|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/01/03/ndaa-obama-indefinite-detention_n_2402601.html|accessdate=4 January 2013|newspaper=The Huffington Post|date=4 January 2013}}</ref>
* The suspect's home country objects to military custody * The suspect is arrested for conduct conducted in the United States * The suspect is originally charged with a non-terrorism offense * The suspect was originally arrested by state or local law enforcement * A transfer to military custody could interfere with efforts to secure cooperation or confession * A transfer would interfere with a joint trial
==Actions from the White House and Senate leading to the vote== The White House threatened to veto the Senate version of the Act,<ref name="whitehouse1"/> arguing in an executive statement on November 17, 2011, that while "the authorities granted by the [[Authorization for Use of Military Force Against Terrorists]], including the detention authority...are essential to our ability to protect the American people...(and) Because the authorities codified in this section already exist, the Administration does not believe codification is necessary and poses some risk".
The statement furthermore objected to the mandate for "military custody for a certain class of terrorism suspects", which it called inconsistent with "the fundamental American principle that our military does not patrol our streets".<ref name="whitehouse1"/> The White House may now waive the requirement for military custody for some detainees following a review by appointed officials including the [[U.S. Attorney General|Attorney General]], the secretaries of state, defense and homeland security, the chairman of the military's Joint Chiefs of Staff and the director of national intelligence.<ref name="NYT28Feb">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/29/us/politics/obama-issues-waivers-on-military-trials-for-foreign-qaeda-suspects.html|title= Obama Issues Waivers on Military Custody for Terror Suspects|date=February 28, 2012 |work= New York Times |accessdate=March 18, 2012 |first=Charlie|last=Savage}}</ref>
During debate within the Senate and before the Act's passage, Senator [[Mark Udall]] introduced an amendment interpreted by the [[ACLU]]<ref name="NDAA" /> and some news sources<ref name="denverpost1" /> as an effort to limit military detention of American citizens indefinitely and without trial. The amendment proposed to strike the section "Detainee Matters" from the bill, and replace section 1021 (then titled 1031) with a provision requiring the Administration to clarify the Executive's authority to detain suspects on the basis of the 2001 [[Authorization for Use of Military Force Against Terrorists]].<ref>[http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CREC-2011-11-17/pdf/CREC-2011-11-17-pt1-PgS7716.pdf#page=13 Udall Amendment Text for SA 1107].</ref> The amendment was rejected by a vote of 60–38 (with 2 abstaining).<ref>[https://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_lists/roll_call_vote_cfm.cfm?congress=112&session=1&vote=00210 U.S. Senate Roll Call Votes 112th Congress – 1st Session]</ref> Udall subsequently voted for the Act in the [[Joint session of the United States Congress|joint session of Congress]] that passed it, and though he remained "extremely troubled" by the detainee provisions, he promised to "push Congress to conduct the maximum amount of oversight possible".<ref name="denverpost1">[http://blogs.denverpost.com/thespot/2011/12/15/beltway-blog-despite-concerns-udall-gives-nod-to-defense-authorization-bill/50286/ "Despite concerns, Udall gives nod to Defense Authorization bill."] ''[[Denver Post]]'', December 15, 2011.</ref>
The Senate later adopted by a 98 to 1 vote a compromise amendment, based upon a proposal by Senator [[Dianne Feinstein]], which preserves current law concerning U.S. citizens and lawful resident aliens detained within the United States.<ref>Gerstein, Josh, [http://www.politico.com/blogs/joshgerstein/1211/Senate_votes_to_allow_indefinite_detention_of_Americans.html "Senate Votes to Allow Indefinite Detention of Americans."] ''[[Politico]]'', December 1, 2011.</ref> After a Senate–House compromise text explicitly ruled out any limitation of the President's authorities, but also removed the ''requirement'' of military detention for terrorism suspects arrested in the United States, the White House issued a statement saying that it would not veto the bill.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/white-house-issues-statement-saying-it-will-not-veto-defense-bill/2011/12/14/gIQApu7PuO_story.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111215212216/http://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/white-house-issues-statement-saying-it-will-not-veto-defense-bill/2011/12/14/gIQApu7PuO_story.html |archive-date=December 15, 2011 |title=White House issues statement saying it will not veto defense bill |publisher=The Washington Post |date=December 14, 2011 |accessdate=December 18, 2011 |deadurl=yes}}</ref>
In his [[Signing Statement]], President Obama explained: "I have signed the Act chiefly because it authorizes funding for the defense of the United States and its interests abroad, crucial services for service members and their families, and vital national security programs that must be renewed...I have signed this bill despite having serious reservations with certain provisions that regulate the detention, interrogation, and prosecution of suspected terrorists".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/index.php?pid=98513&st=&st1=#axzz1iE5qy7a3 |title=Barack Obama: Statement on Signing the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2012 |publisher=Presidency.ucsb.edu |date=2011-12-31 |accessdate=2012-02-27}}</ref>
==The vote== [[File:NDAA 2012 House vote.svg|thumb|300px|House vote by congressional district. {{legend|#000080|Democratic nay}} {{legend|#5050FF|Democratic yea}} {{legend|#800000|Republican yea}} {{legend|#FF5050|Republican nay}} {{legend|#C8C8C8|Absent or no representative seated}}]] [[File:NDAA 2012 Senate vote.svg|thumb|300px|Senate vote by state. {{legend|#000080|Both yes}} {{legend|#0066FF|One yes, one didn't vote}} {{legend|#D42AFF|One yes, one no}} {{legend|#D40000|One no, one didn't vote}} {{legend|#800000|Both no}}]]
On December 14, 2011, the bill passed the U.S. House by a vote of 283 to 136, with 19 representatives not voting,<ref>http://votesmart.org/bill/votes/37467#.UK8rh4bll8M|title=HR</ref> and passed by the U.S. Senate on December 15, 2011, by a vote of 86 to 13.<ref>http://votesmart.org/bill/votes/37472#.UK8oqYbll8M|title=HR</ref>
==Controversy over indefinite detention== [[File:Repeals Indefinite Military Detention Provisions House vote.svg|thumb|left|300px|'''H Amdt 1127 Repeals Indefinite Military Detention Provisions'''<br>House vote by congressional district.<ref>[https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/112-2012/h270 On Agreeing to the Amendment: Amendment 29 to H R 4310]</ref> {{legend|#000080|Democratic yea}} {{legend|#5050FF|Democratic nay}} {{legend|#FF5050|Republican yea}} {{legend|#800000|Republican nay}} {{legend|#C8C8C8|Absent or no representative seated}}]] [[File:S Amdt 3018 - Prohibits the Indefinite Detention of Citizens and Lawful Permanent Residents.svg|thumb|left|300px|''' S Amdt 3018 – Prohibits the Indefinite Detention of Citizens and Lawful Permanent Residents'''<br>Senate vote by state.<ref>[https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/112-2012/s213 On the Amendment S.Amdt. 3018 to S. 3254 (National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2013)]</ref> {{legend|#000080|Both yes}} {{legend|#0066FF|One yes, one didn't vote}} {{legend|#D42AFF|One yes, one no}} {{legend|#D40000|One no, one didn't vote}} {{legend|#800000|Both no}}]]
{{Quote box|width=30em|fontsize = 90%|bgcolor = #F0F0F0|quote=Section 1021.... Congress affirms that the authority of the President to use all necessary and appropriate force pursuant to the Authorization for Use of Military Force ... includes the authority for the Armed Forces of the United States to detain covered persons (as defined in subsection (b)) pending disposition under the law of war. … Section 1022. …. Except as provided in paragraph (4), the Armed Forces of the United States shall hold a person described in paragraph (2) who is captured in the course of hostilities authorized by the Authorization for Use of Military Force ... in military custody pending disposition under the law of war.|align=right|source= — Excerpts from NDAA 2012, sections 1021 and 1022.<ref>http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/PLAW-112publ81/pdf/PLAW-112publ81.pdf</ref> }}
===American and international reactions=== Section 1021 and 1022 have been called a violation of constitutional principles and of the [[United States Bill of Rights|Bill of Rights]].<ref>"Commentary: trampling the bill of rights in defense's name." ''[[The Kansas City Star]]'', 14 December 2011: {{cite web |url=http://www.kansascity.com/2011/12/14/3315738/commentary-trampling-the-bill.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-12-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120106111552/http://www.kansascity.com/2011/12/14/3315738/commentary-trampling-the-bill.html |archivedate=2012-01-06 |df= }}.</ref> Internationally, the UK-based newspaper ''[[The Guardian]]'' has described the legislation as allowing indefinite detention "without trial [of] American terrorism suspects arrested on U.S. soil who could then be shipped to [[Guantánamo Bay]];"<ref>McGreal, C., "Military given go-ahead to detain US terrorist suspects without trial", ''[[The Guardian]]'', 14 December 2011: [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/dec/15/americans-face-guantanamo-detention-obama].</ref> ''[[Al Jazeera]]'' has written that the Act "gives the U.S. military the option to detain U.S. citizens suspected of participating or aiding in terrorist activities without a trial, indefinitely".<ref>Parvaz, D., "US lawmakers legalise indefinite detention", ''[[Al Jazeera]]'', 16 December 2011: [http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2011/12/201112773810926474.html].</ref> The official Russian international radio broadcasting service ''[[Voice of Russia]]'' has been highly critical of the legislation, writing that under its authority "the U.S. military will have the power to detain Americans suspected of involvement in terrorism without charge or trial and imprison them for an indefinite period of time"; it has furthermore written that "the most radical analysts are comparing the new law to the edicts of the '[[Nazi Germany|Third Reich]]' or 'Muslim tyrannies'".<ref>Kramnik, Ilya "New US Defense Act curtails liberties not military spending," ''[[Voice of Russia]]'', 28 December 2011.</ref> The Act was strongly opposed by the [[ACLU]], [[Amnesty International]], [[Human Rights First]], [[Human Rights Watch]], [[The Center for Constitutional Rights]], the [[Cato Institute]], ''[[Reason Magazine]]'', and [[The Council on American-Islamic Relations]], and was criticized in editorials published in the ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]''<ref>Rosenthal, A., "President Obama: Veto the Defense Authorization Act," ''[[The New York Times]]'', 30 November 2011: [http://loyalopposition.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/11/30/president-obama-veto-the-defense-authorization-act/].</ref> and other news organizations.<ref>Grey, B. and T. Carter, "The Nation and the National Defense Authorization Act", ''[[World Socialist Web Site]]'', 27 December 2011: [http://www.wsws.org/articles/2011/dec2011/ndaa-d27.shtml].</ref><ref>E.D. Kain: ''[https://www.forbes.com/sites/erikkain/2011/12/05/the-national-defense-authorization-act-is-the-greatest-threat-to-civil-liberties-americans-face/ The National Defense Authorization Act is the Greatest Threat to Civil Liberties Americans Face].'' In: ''[[Forbes]].'' December 5, 2011</ref>
Americans have sought resistance of the NDAA through successful resolution campaigns in various states and municipalities. The states of Rhode Island and Michigan, the Colorado counties of Wade, El Paso, and Fremont, as well as the municipalities of Northampton, MA. and Fairfax, CA, have all passed resolutions rejecting the indefinite detention provisions of the NDAA.<ref>{{cite web|title=NDAA: Liberty Preservation Act Tracking|url=http://tenthamendmentcenter.com/nullification/ndaa/|publisher=Tenth Amendment Center|accessdate=29 May 2012}}</ref> The [[Bill of Rights Defense Committee]] has launched a [http://constitutioncampaign.org/campaigns/dueprocess/ national campaign] to mobilize individuals at the grassroots level to pass local and state resolutions voicing opposition to the NDAA. Campaigns have begun to grow in New York City, Miami and San Diego, among other cities and states.<ref>http://constitutioncampaign.org/campaigns/dueprocess/maps.php></ref>
Attorneys Carl J. Mayer and Bruce I. Afran filed a complaint January 13, 2012, in the Southern U.S. District Court in New York City on the behalf of [[Chris Hedges]] against Barack Obama and Secretary of Defense Leon Panetta to challenge the legality of the Authorization for Use of Military Force as embedded in the latest version of the National Defense Authorization Act, signed by the president December 31.<ref name="Hedges20120116">{{cite web|last=Hedges|first=Chris|title=Why I'm Suing Barack Obama|url=http://www.commondreams.org/view/2012/01/16|publisher=Common Dreams|accessdate=29 May 2012|date=16 January 2012}}</ref> Lt. Col. Barry Wingard, a military attorney representing prisoners at [[Guantanamo Bay Detention Camp]], noted that under the NDAA "an American citizen can be detained forever without trial, while the allegations against you go uncontested because you have no right to see them".<ref>{{cite news|last=Thomas|first=Lillian|title=A military attorney's access to his Guantanamo client eroded|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/stories/news/world/a-military-attorneys-access-to-his-guantanamo-client-eroded-655532/|accessdate=30 September 2012|newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|date=30 September 2012}}</ref>
===Views of the Obama Administration=== On December 31, 2011, and after signing the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2012 into law, President Obama issued a statement on it addressing "certain provisions that regulate the detention, interrogation, and prosecution of terrorism suspects". In the statement the President maintains that "the legislation does nothing more than confirm authorities that the Federal courts have recognized as lawful under the 2001 AUMF". The statement also maintains that the "Administration will not authorize the indefinite military detention without trial of American citizens", and that it "will interpret section 1021 in a manner that ensures that any detention it authorizes complies with the Constitution, the laws of war, and all other applicable law". Referring to the applicability of civilian versus military detention, the statement argued that "the only responsible way to combat the threat al-Qa'ida poses is to remain relentlessly practical, guided by the factual and legal complexities of each case and the relative strengths and weaknesses of each system. Otherwise, investigations could be compromised, our authorities to hold dangerous individuals could be jeopardized, and intelligence could be lost".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/index.php?pid=98513&st=&st1=#axzz1iE5qy7a3|title=Barack Obama: Statement on Signing the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2012|publisher=John T. Woolley and Gerhard Peters, The American Presidency Project [online]|date=December 31, 2011|accessdate=2012-01-01}}</ref>
On February 22, 2012, the Administration represented by [[Jeh Charles Johnson]], [[General Counsel of the Department of Defense|General Counsel of the U.S. Department of Defense]] defined the term "associated forces". Johnson stated in a speech at [[Yale Law School]]:
{{quote|An "associated force," as we interpret the phrase, has two characteristics to it: (1) an organized, armed group that has entered the fight alongside al Qaeda, and (2) is a co-belligerent with al Qaeda in hostilities against the United States or its coalition partners. In other words, the group must not only be aligned with al Qaeda. It must have also entered the fight against the United States or its coalition partners. Thus, an "associated force" is not any terrorist group in the world that merely embraces the al Qaeda ideology.<ref>{{cite web|last=Johnson|first=Jeh Charles|title=Jeh Johnson’s Speech on "National Security Law, Lawyers and Lawyering in the Obama Administration" – Dean’s Lecture at Yale Law School on February 22, 2012|url=http://www.cfr.org/national-security-and-defense/jeh-johnsons-speech-national-security-law-lawyers-lawyering-obama-administration/p27448|publisher=Council on Foreign Relations|accessdate=16 November 2012|date=22 February 2012}}</ref>}}
On February 28, 2012, the administration announced that it would waive the requirement for military detention in "any case in which officials [believe] that placing a detainee in military custody could impede [[counterterrorism]] cooperation with the detainee's home government or interfere with efforts to secure the person's cooperation or confession".<ref name="NYT28Feb" /> Application of military custody to any suspect is determined by a national security team including the attorney general, the secretaries of state, defense, and homeland security, the chairman of the [[Joint Chiefs of Staff]], and the [[Director of National Intelligence]].<ref name="NYT28Feb" />
On September 12, 2012, U.S. District Judge [[Katherine B. Forrest]] issued an injunction against the indefinite detention provisions of the NDAA (section 1021(b)(2)) on the grounds of unconstitutionality; however, this injunction was appealed to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit the following day and was later reversed.<ref name="Bloomberg20120913">{{cite news|last=Van Voris|first=Bob|title=U.S. Appeals Order Blocking U.S. Military Detention Law|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-09-13/u-s-appeals-order-blocking-u-s-military-detention-law.html|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=14 September 2012|date=13 September 2012}}</ref><ref name="Reuters20120914">{{cite news|last=Katz|first=Basil|title=REFILE-U.S. calls ruling on military detention law harmful|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/09/14/usa-security-lawsuit-idINL1E8KEEOP20120914?irpc=932|publisher=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=16 September 2012|date=14 September 2012}}</ref>
The Administration explained on November 6, 2012, the terms "substantially supported" and "associated forces" in its opening brief before the U.S. Second Court of Appeals in ''[[Hedges v. Obama]]''.<ref name="HVOBrief20121106">{{cite web|url=http://assets.fiercemarkets.net/public/sites/govit/hedges.pdf|title=United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit Case: 12-3644 Document: 69 11/06/2012 761770 Brief for the Appellants|first=|date=6 November 2012|website=|publisher=|accessdate=16 November 2012|author1=Preet Bharara|author2=Benjamin H. Torrance|author3=Christopher B. Harwood|author4=Jeh Charles Johnson|author5=Stuart F. Delery|author6=Beth S. Brinkmann|author7=Robert M. Loeb|author8=August E. Flentje}}</ref> With respect to the term "substantially supported" the Obama administration stated:
{{quote|The term "substantial support" covers support that, in analogous circumstances in a traditional international armed conflict, is sufficient to justify detention. The term thus encompasses individuals who, even if not considered part of the irregular enemy forces at issue in [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|the current conflict]], bear sufficiently close ties to those forces and provide them support that warrants their detention in prosecution of the conflict. See, e.g., [[Third Geneva Convention|Geneva Convention III]], Art. 4.A(4) (encompassing detention of individuals who "accompany the armed forces without actually being members thereof, such as civilian members of military aircraft crews, war correspondents, supply contractors, members of labour units or of services responsible for the welfare of the armed forces, provided that they have received authorization from the armed forces which they accompany"); Int'l Comm. Of the Red Cross Commentary on Third Geneva Convention 64 (Pictet, ed. 1960) (Art. 4(a)(4) intended to encompass certain "classes of persons who were more or less part of the armed force" while not members thereof); ''see also, e.g., Gov't Br. in Al Bihani v. Obama'', No. 99-5051, 2009 WL 2957826, at 41–42 (D.C. Cir. Sept. 15, 2009) (explaining that petitioner "was unequivocally part of" an enemy force, but even if he "was not part of enemy forces, he accompanied those forces on the battlefield and performed services (e.g. cooking, guard duty)" for them that justified military detention). Under those principles, the term "substantially support" cannot give rise to any reasonable fear that it will be applied to the types of independent journalism or advocacy at issue here. See March 2009 Mem. at 2 ("substantially support" does not include those who provide "unwitting or insignificant support" to al-Qaeda); ''cf. Bensayah'', 610 F.3d at 722, 725 ("purely independent conduct of a freelancer is not enough"). [...] the "substantial support" prong addresses actions like "plan[ning] to take up arms against the United States" on behalf of al-Qaeda and "facilitat[ing] the travel of unnamed others to do the same." Page 35-37, 61 in<ref name="HVOBrief20121106" />}}
And with respect to the term "associated forces", the Administration cited the above-mentioned Jeh Johnson's remarks on February 22, 2012:
{{quote|That term [associated forces] is well understood to cover cobelligerent groups that fight together with al-Qaeda or Taliban forces in the armed conflict against the United States or its coalition partners. [...] after carefully considering how traditional law-of-war concepts apply in [[War on Terror|this armed conflict against non-state armed groups]], the government has made clear that an "'associated force' . . . has two characteristics": (1) an organized, armed group that has entered the fight alongside al Qaeda, [that] (2) is a co-belligerent with al Qaeda in hostilities against the United States or its coalition partners.<ref name="HVOBrief20121106" />}}
The Administration summarized later in its brief that:
{{quote|an associated force is an "organized, armed group that has entered the fight alongside al Qaeda" or the Taliban and is "a cobelligerent with al Qaeda [or the Taliban] in hostilities against the United States or its coalition partners." Page 60-61 in<ref name="HVOBrief20121106" />}}
NBC News released in February 2014 an undated U.S. Department of Justice White paper entitled "Lawfulness of a Lethal Operation Directed Against a U.S. Citizen who is a Senior Operational Leader of Al Qa'ida or An Associated Force."<ref name="NBCIsikoff20140204">{{cite news|last1=Isikoff|first1=Michael|title=Justice Department memo reveals legal case for drone strikes on Americans|accessdate=15 August 2014|work=NBC News|date=4 February 2013|url=http://investigations.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/02/04/16843014-justice-department-memo-reveals-legal-case-for-drone-strikes-on-americans?lite}}</ref> In it the Justice Department stated with respect to the term "associated forces"
{{quote|An associated force of al-Qa'ida includes a group that would qualify as a co-belligerent under the laws of war. See ''Hamily v. Obama'', 616 F. Supp. 2d 63, 74–75 (D.D.C. 2009) (authority to detain extends to "associated forces," which "mean 'co-belligerents' as that term is understood under the laws of war"). (Footnote at page 1 in<ref>{{cite web|title=Undated memo entitled "Lawfulness of a Lethal Operation Directed Against a U.S. Citizen who is a Senior Operational Leader of Al Qa'ida or An Associated Force." by the U.S. Department of Justice|url=http://msnbcmedia.msn.com/i/msnbc/sections/news/020413_DOJ_White_Paper.pdf|publisher=NBC News|accessdate=15 August 2014}}</ref>}}
===Legal arguments that the legislation does not allow the indefinite detention of U.S. citizens=== ''[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]'' wrote that the Act "is the first concrete gesture Congress has made towards turning the homeland into the battlefield", arguing that "codifying indefinite detention on American soil is a very dangerous step". The magazine has nevertheless contested claims by ''[[The Guardian]]'' and the ''[[New York Times]]'' that the Act "allows the military to indefinitely detain without trial American terrorism suspects arrested on U.S. soil who could then be shipped to [[Guantánamo Bay]]", writing that "they're simply wrong...It allows people who think the 2001 Authorization to Use Military Force against the perpetrators of the 9/11 attacks gives the president the authority to detain U.S. citizens without charge or trial to say that, but it also allows people who can read the Constitution of the United States to argue something else".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://motherjones.com/mojo/2011/12/defense-bill-passed-so-what-does-it-do-ndaa|title=The Defense Bill Passed. So What Does It Do?|work=Mother Jones|access-date=2017-07-11|language=en-US}}</ref> Legal commentator Joanne Mariner has noted in ''Verdict'' that the scope of existing detention power under the [[Authorization for Use of Military Force Against Terrorists|AUMF]] is "subject to vociferous debate and continuing litigation".<ref name="NDAAexplained">{{cite web|url=http://verdict.justia.com/2012/01/02/the-ndaa-explained |title=The NDAA Explained |work=Verdict |date=2 January 2012}}</ref> In the years that followed the [[September 11 attacks]], the AUMF was interpreted to allow the indefinite detention of both citizens and non-citizens arrested far from any traditional battlefield, including in the United States. {{Citation needed|reason=where's the source for that statement?|date=October 2016}}
Other legal commentators argue that the NDAA does not permit truly "indefinite" detention, given that the period of detention is limited by the duration of the armed conflict. In making this claim, they emphasize the difference between (1) detention pursuant to the "[[laws of war]]" and (2) detention pursuant to domestic criminal law authorities.<ref name="rivkin">[http://justourfreedom.wordpress.com/2011/11/02/bill%E2%80%99s-detainee-provisions-reaffirm-the-law-of-war/ "Rivkin & Casey, Bill's detainee provisions reaffirm the laws of war."]</ref> [[David B. Rivkin]] and Lee Casey, for example, argue that detention under the AUMF is authorized under the laws of war and is not indefinite because the authority to detain ends with the cessation of hostilities. They argue that the NDAA invokes "existing Supreme Court precedent...that clearly permits the military detention (and even trial) of citizens who have themselves engaged in hostile acts or have supported such acts to the extent that they are properly classified as 'combatants' or 'belligerents'". This reflects the fact that, in their view, the United States is, pursuant to the AUMF, at war with al-Qaeda, and detention of enemy combatants in accordance with the laws of war is authorized. In their view, this does not preclude trial in civilian courts, but it does not require that the detainee be charged and tried. If the detainee is an enemy combatant who has not violated the laws of war, he is not chargeable with any triable offense. Commentators who share this view emphasize the need not to blur the distinction between domestic criminal law and the laws of war.<ref name=rivkin/><ref name="ICRC-210705">[[International Committee of the Red Cross|ICRC]] official statement: ''[http://www.icrc.org/web/eng/siteeng0.nsf/html/terrorism-ihl-210705 The relevance of IHL in the context of terrorism]'', 21 July 2005</ref>
===Legal arguments that the legislation allows indefinite detention=== The [[American Civil Liberties Union]] has stated that "While President Obama issued a signing statement saying he had 'serious reservations' about the provisions, the statement only applies to how his administration would use the authorities granted by the NDAA", and, despite claims to the contrary, "The statute contains a sweeping worldwide indefinite detention provision...[without] temporal or geographic limitations, and can be used by this and future presidents to militarily detain people captured far from any battlefield". The ACLU also maintains that "the breadth of the NDAA's detention authority violates international law because it is not limited to people captured in the context of an actual armed conflict as required by the laws of war".<ref>"[https://www.aclu.org/national-security/president-obama-signs-indefinite-detention-bill-law President Obama Signs Indefinite Detention Bill Into Law]", [[ACLU]], 31 December 2011.</ref>
===Proposed legislative reforms=== Following the passage of the NDAA, various proposals have been offered to clarify the detainee provisions. One example, [http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.uscongress/legislation.112hr3676 H.R. 3676], sponsored by U.S. Representative [[Jeff Landry]] of [[Louisiana]], would amend the NDAA "to specify that no U.S. citizen may be detained against his or her will without all the rights of [[due process]]".<ref name="Summary">[http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d112:H.R.3676:@@@D&summ2=m& Library of Congress: Thomas].</ref> Other similar bills in the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. House of Representatives]] have been introduced by Representatives [[John Garamendi]] of [[California]] and [[Chris Gibson (New York politician)|Chris Gibson]] of [[New York (state)|New York]].
The [[National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2013|Feinstein-Lee Amendment]] that would have explicitly barred the military from holding American citizens and permanent residents in indefinite detention without trial as terrorism suspects was dropped on December 18, 2012, during the merging of the House and Senate versions of the 2013 National Defense Authorization Act.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bell|first=Zachary|title=NDAA's indefinite detention without trial returns|url=http://www.salon.com/2012/12/19/ndaas_indefinite_detention_without_trial_returns/|publisher=salon.com|accessdate=20 December 2012|date=20 December 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Savage|first=Charlie|title=Congressional Negotiators Drop Ban on Indefinite Detention of Citizens, Aides Say|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/19/us/politics/congressional-committee-is-said-to-drop-ban-on-indefinite-detention-of-citizens.html?_r=0|accessdate=20 December 2012|newspaper=New York Times|date=18 December 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Kelley|first=Michael|title=Lawyers Fighting NDAA Indefinite Detention Slam Congress' Latest Decision|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/lawyers-mad-about-feinstein-amendment-2012-12|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=20 December 2012|date=19 December 2012}}</ref>
==Legal challenges to indefinite detention== ===''Hedges v. Obama''=== {{Main|Hedges v. Obama}}
A lawsuit was filed January 13, 2012, against the [[Presidency of Barack Obama|Obama Administration]] and Members of the U.S. Congress by a group including former ''New York Times'' reporter [[Christopher Hedges]] challenging the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2012.<ref name="Bloomberg20120913" /> The plaintiffs contend that Section 1021(b)(2) of the law allows the detention of citizens and permanent residents taken into custody in the United States on "suspicion of providing substantial support" to groups engaged in hostilities against the United States such as al-Qaeda and the Taliban.<ref name="Bloomberg20120913" />
In May 2012, a federal court in New York issued a preliminary injunction which temporarily blocked the indefinite detention powers of NDAA Section 1021(b)(2) on the grounds of unconstitutionality.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite news|title=Military Detention Law Blocked By New York Judge|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-05-16/military-detention-law-blocked-by-new-york-judge.html|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=29 May 2012|author1=Bob Van Voris |author2=Patricia Hurtado |lastauthoramp=yes |date=17 May 2012}}</ref> On August 6, 2012, federal prosecutors representing President Obama and Defense Secretary [[Leon Panetta]] filed a notice of appeal with the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit]], hoping to eliminate the ban.<ref name="RT20120807">{{cite web|title=Obama fights ban on indefinite detention of Americans|url=http://rt.com/usa/news/obama-indefinite-detention-forrest-070/|publisher=RT News|accessdate=23 August 2012|date=7 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Indefinite Detention Ruling Appealed By Federal Prosecutors|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/08/07/indefinite-detention-ruling_n_1749566.html#slide=more228606|work=Reuters|publisher=The Huffington Post|accessdate=23 August 2012|date=6 August 2012}}</ref> The following day arguments from both sides were heard by U.S. District Judge [[Katherine B. Forrest]] during a hearing to determine whether to make her [[preliminary injunction]] permanent or not.<ref name="Pinto20120807">{{cite web|last=Pinto|first=Nick|title=NDAA Suit Argued In Federal Court Yesterday|url=http://blogs.villagevoice.com/runninscared/2012/08/ndaa_suit_argue.php|publisher=The Village Voice Blogs|accessdate=23 August 2012|date=7 August 2012}}</ref> On September 12, 2012, Judge Forrest issued a permanent injunction,<ref name="DemocracyNow20120913">{{cite web|title=Judge Permanently Blocks Indefinite Detention Provision in NDAA|url=http://www.democracynow.org/2012/9/13/headlines/judge_permanently_blocks_indefinite_detention_provision_in_ndaa|publisher=Democracy Now|accessdate=14 September 2012|date=13 September 2012}}</ref> but this was appealed by the Obama Administration on September 13, 2012.<ref name="Bloomberg20120913" /><ref name="Reuters20120914" /> A federal appeals court granted a U.S. Justice Department's request for an interim [[Stay of execution|stay]] of the permanent injunction, pending the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit|Second Circuit's]] consideration of the government's motion to stay the injunction throughout its appeal.<ref name="Lawfare20120918">{{cite web|last=Bennett|first=Wells C.|title=Stay You, Stay Me: CA2 Enters Interim Stay Order in Hedges|url=http://www.lawfareblog.com/2012/09/stay-you-stay-me-ca2-enters-interim-stay-order-in-hedges/|publisher=Lawfare: Hard National Security Choices|accessdate=18 September 2012|date=18 September 2012}}</ref><ref name="NYT20120917">{{cite news|last=Savage|first=Charlie|title=U.S. Warns Judge's Ruling Impedes Its Detention Powers|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/18/us/politics/us-warns-judges-ruling-impedes-its-detention-powers.html?_r=2&pagewanted=all|accessdate=20 September 2012|newspaper=New York Times|date=17 September 2012}}</ref><ref name="NYT20120918">{{cite news|last=Savage|first=Charlie|title=U.S. Appeals Judge Grants Stay of Ruling on Detention Law|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/19/us/politics/us-appeals-judge-grants-stay-of-ruling-on-detention-law.html?ref=charliesavage|accessdate=20 September 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=18 September 2012}}</ref> The court also said that a Second Circuit motions panel will take up the government's motion for stay pending appeal on September 28, 2012.<ref name="Lawfare20120918" /><ref name="NYT20120917" /><ref name="NYT20120918" /> On October 2, 2012, the Second Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that the ban on indefinite detention will not go into effect until a decision on the Obama Administration's appeal is rendered.<ref name="Reuters20121002">{{cite web|last=Katz|first=Basil|title=U.S. appeals court to hear military detention case|url=http://newsandinsight.thomsonreuters.com/Legal/News/2012/10_-_October/U_S__appeals_court_to_hear_military_detention_case/|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=3 October 2012|date=2 October 2012}}</ref> The U.S. Supreme Court refused on December 14, 2012, to lift the stay pending appeal of the order issued by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit on October 2, 2012.<ref name="Lawfare20121213">{{cite web|last=Bennett|first=Wells|title=Hedges Plaintiffs Ask SCOTUS to Vacate CA2 Stay|url=http://www.lawfareblog.com/2012/12/hedges-plaintiffs-ask-scotus-to-vacate-ca2-stay/|publisher=Lawfare Blog – Hard National Security Choices|accessdate=15 December 2012|date=13 December 2012}}</ref> The Second Circuit Court of Appeals overturned on July 17, 2013, the district court's ruling which struck down § 1021(b)(2) of NDAA as unconstitutional, because the plaintiffs lacked [[legal standing]] to challenge it.<ref name="Bloomberg20130717">{{cite news|last=Dolmetsch|first=Chris|title=Ruling That Struck Down Military Detention Power Rejected|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-07-17/ruling-that-struck-down-military-detention-power-rejected.html|accessdate=20 July 2013|newspaper=Bloomberg News|date=17 July 2013}}</ref> The Supreme Court denied certiorari in an order issued April 28, 2014.<ref name="USC20140428">{{cite web|title=Order List: 572 U. S. 13-758 HEDGES, CHRISTOPHER, ET AL. V. OBAMA, PRES. OF U.S., ET AL. – Certiorari Denied|work=United States Supreme Court|publisher=United States Supreme Court|accessdate=29 April 2014|page=7|url=https://www.supremecourt.gov/orders/courtorders/042814zor_6k47.pdf|date=29 April 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Denniston|first=Lyle|title=Detention challenge denied|url=http://www.scotusblog.com/2014/04/detention-challenge-denied/|publisher=SCOTUSblog|accessdate=29 April 2014|date=28 April 2014}}</ref> Critics of the decision quickly pointed out that, without the right to a trial, it is impossible for an individual with [[legal standing]] to challenge 1021 without having already been released.
===States taking action against indefinite detention sections of NDAA=== As of April 2013, four states have passed resolutions through committee to adjust or block the detainment provisions of the 2012 NDAA and now await a vote. These states are: Arizona, Colorado, Montana, and South Carolina.<ref name="pandaunite.org">[http://www.pandaunite.org/resources/anti-ndaa-legislativetracking Retrieved 21 May 2013|www.pandaunite.org]</ref> Anti-NDAA legislation has passed the full senate in Indiana by a vote of 31–17.<ref name="pandaunite.org"/> In Kansas, legislation is waiting for a vote.<ref name="pandaunite.org"/> An additional 13 states have introduced legislation against the detainment provisions: California, Georgia, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Missouri, Nevada, New Hampshire, North Carolina, Oklahoma, Tennessee, Texas, and West Virginia.<ref>[http://www.pandaunite.org/resources/anti-ndaa-legislativetracking|www.pandaunite.org]</ref>
===Counties and municipalities taking action against indefinite detention sections of NDAA=== Nine counties have passed resolutions against sections 1021 and 1022 of the NDAA. They are: [[Moffat County, Colorado|Moffat]], [[Weld County, Colorado|Weld]], and [[Fremont County, Colorado|Fremont]] counties in Colorado; [[Harper County, Kansas|Harper County]], Kansas; Allegan and Oakland counties in Michigan; [[Alleghany County, North Carolina|Alleghany County]] in North Carolina; and [[Fulton County, Pennsylvania|Fulton]] and [[Elk County, Pennsylvania|Elk]] counties in Pennsylvania.<ref name="pandaunite.org"/> Resolutions have been introduced in three counties: [[Barber County, Kansas|Barber County]], Kansas; [[Montgomery County, Maryland|Montgomery County]], Maryland; and [[Lycoming County]], Pennsylvania.<ref name="pandaunite.org"/>
Eleven municipalities have passed resolutions as well. They are: Berkeley, Fairfax, San Francisco, and Santa Cruz, California; Cherokee City, Kansas; [[Northampton, Massachusetts|Northampton]], Massachusetts; [[Takoma Park, Maryland|Takoma Park]], Maryland; [[Macomb, New York|Macomb]], New York; New Shorehampton, Rhode Island; [[League City, Texas]]; and [[Las Vegas]], Nevada (currently waiting on the county to pass a joint resolution).<ref name="pandaunite.org"/> An additional 13 municipalities have introduced anti-NDAA resolutions: [[San Diego]], California; Miami, Florida; [[Portland, Maine]]; Chapel Hill, Durham, and Raleigh, North Carolina; [[Albuquerque]], New Mexico; Albany and New York City, New York; [[Tulsa]], Oklahoma; Dallas, Texas; Springfield, Virginia; and Tacoma, Washington.<ref name="pandaunite.org"/>
Northampton, Massachusetts, became the first city in [[New England]] to pass a resolution rejecting the NDAA on February 16, 2012.<ref name="pandaunite.org"/> William Newman, Director of the [[ACLU]] in western Massachusetts, said, "We have a country based on laws and process and fairness. This law is an absolute affront to those principles that make America a free nation".<ref>[http://www.wwlp.com/dpp/news/northampton-opts-out-of-federal-law Northampton "opts out" of federal law | WWLP.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Sanctions targeting the Iranian Central Bank== {{Main|U.S. sanctions against Iran}} As part of the ongoing dispute over [[Nuclear program of Iran|Iranian uranium enrichment]], section 1245 of the NDAA imposes unilateral sanctions against the [[Central Bank]] of Iran, effectively blocking Iranian oil exports to countries which do business with the United States.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ca.reuters.com/article/topNews/idCATRE7BU09420111231?sp=true|title=U.S. steps up sanctions as Iran floats nuclear talks|publisher=Reuters Canada|author1=MacInnis, Laura |author2=Parisa Hafezi |lastauthoramp=yes |date=31 December 2011|accessdate=2012-01-05}}</ref><ref name="wsj-iran-central-bank">{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204720204577132923798499772|title=U.S. Targets Iran's Central Bank|publisher=Wall Street Journal |author1=Lee, Carol E. |author2=Keith Johnson |lastauthoramp=yes |date=4 January 2012|accessdate=2012-01-05}}</ref> The new sanctions impose penalties against entities—including corporations and foreign central banks—which engage in transactions with the Iranian central bank. Sanctions on transactions unrelated to petroleum take effect 60 days after the bill is signed into law, while sanctions on transactions related to petroleum take effect a minimum of six months after the bill's signing.<ref name="wsj-iran-central-bank"/> The bill grants the U.S. President authority to grant waivers in cases in which petroleum purchasers are unable, due to supply or cost, to significantly reduce their purchases of Iranian oil, or in which American national security is threatened by implementation of the sanctions.<ref name="wsj-iran-central-bank"/><ref name="reuters-india">{{cite news|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2012/01/01/iran-usa-obama-idINDEE80001720120101?feedType=RSS&feedName=globalCoverage2|title=U.S. imposes sanctions on banks dealing with Iran|publisher=Reuters India|author=MacInnis, Laura|date=1 January 2012|accessdate=2012-01-05}}</ref> Following the signing into law of the NDAA, the [[Iranian rial]] fell significantly against the U.S. dollar, reaching a record low two days after the bill's enactment, a change widely attributed to the expected impact of the new sanctions on the Iranian economy.<ref name="LATimes-sanctions-toll">{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-iran-obama-20120110,0,134568.story|title=Sanctions begin taking a bigger toll on Iran|publisher=Los Angeles Times|author1=Richter, Paul |author2=Ramin Mostaghim |lastauthoramp=yes |date=9 January 2012|accessdate=2012-01-11}}</ref><ref name="WSJ-Iran-currency">{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970203513604577140642815644090 |title=Sanctions on Iran Whipsaw Currency |publisher=Wall Street Journal |date=4 January 2012 |accessdate=2012-01-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120114233910/http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052970203513604577140642815644090.html |archivedate=January 14, 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref name="NYT-Iran-currency">{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-iran-obama-20120110,0,134568.story|title=As Further Sanctions Loom, Plunge in Currency's Value Unsettles Sanctions|author1=Sanger, David E. |author2=Annie Lowrey |lastauthoramp=yes |date=27 December 2011|accessdate=2012-01-11|work=The New York Times}}</ref>
==Military pay and benefits== Amendments made to the bill following its passage include a 1.6 percent pay increase for all service members, and an increase in military healthcare enrollment and copay fees. The changes were unanimously endorsed by the [[Senate Armed Services Committee]].<ref name="Howell20110620">{{cite web|last=Howell|first=Terry|title=2012 Defense Act – Pay Increase, Changes to Special Pay and TRICARE|url=http://militaryadvantage.military.com/2011/06/senate-okays-pay-and-tricare-fee-increase/|publisher=Military.com|accessdate=3 August 2012|date=20 June 2011}}</ref>
